As I have put it, the Snowy is a national icon. There ought to be a substantive Commonwealth national policy interest and there are national policy issues to be considered here.

Some of the things which the water inquiry needs to focus on, and I am sure will focus on, include the views of all interested parties—irrigators, environment interests and other downstream users of the water; the financial consequences of changed allocations, if any; and the nature and extent of those changed allocations.

The Labor senators, in the minority report, had in their recommendation a suggestion which is not dissimilar to the detailed committee stage amendment which I will move. Mr Deputy Speaker, I have some considerable time left but I think I have covered the issues in the nature of the debate in this chamber. I am quite happy to formally now move the amendment that has been circulated in my name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew, Neil, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to participate in this debate, to reflect on the amendment moved by the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) and on the motives behind that amendment, and to make a comment or two about my involvement both as a South Australian dependent on the waters of the Snowy and as an irrigator concerned about the quality of the water that flows through the Murray‐Darling Basin system.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment moved by the member for Perth reflects what are understandable community concerns. But they are also largely unfounded community concerns. It is a bit of a case, in this instance, of the opposition wanting both to have its cake and eat it too. To quote from the member for Perth's participation in this debate a few minutes ago, he said that much of the enthusiasm for his amendment came from those who sought simply, in his words, to `let the river run free'.

That is the sort of emotive sentiment that is largely embraced by a range of people participating in this debate. It is the sort of emotive sentiment with which I could easily be identified because I, too, would like to stand and watch all rivers run free, unhampered as it were by the activities of people who have chosen, for one reason or another, to restrict various rivers' flow.

The point about this legislation and the point about the amendment moved by the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) is that this legislation seeks to do what is environmentally responsible. This legislation seeks to ensure that the diverted waters of the Snowy are used for the most effective power generation possible. The member for Perth and, I suspect, those from the opposition who will follow him in proposing this amendment to the legislation, are, as I said in my opening remarks, seeking simply to have their cake and eat it too and to make all of the noises about being green but not accept the responsibility of taking difficult decisions in order to ensure that the green nature and the environmental sensitivity of the Snowy, and those rivers dependent on it, are preserved.

BREAK.PARA: The situation simply is this: as a nation we are now largely dependent on the diverted waters of the Snowy scheme for efficient power generation. There is probably no other place in Australia, not even in the home state of Tasmania of the member for Denison (Mr Kerr), in which power is as efficiently generated as it is in the Snowy. I would be happy, by the way, to withdraw that if the member for Denison could give me evidence but I am sure he and I would mutually agree that hydro-electricity represents a very renewable form of energy that all Australians welcome.

It is easy to move glib resolutions and amendments about what ought to be done without recognising the simple truth that we have become dependent on the Snowy scheme for the efficient generation of electricity. Making more water available for other purposes will be, in one degree or another, at the expense of the efficient generation of electricity out of the Snowy River hydro scheme.

Every Australian is proud of the Snowy River diversion; every Australian is proud of this massive capital expenditure which diverted water from the Snowy and sent it west through a myriad of tunnels and aqueducts so that power was being generated as the water fell and that, simultaneously, additional water was available through the Murray and Murrumbidgee irrigation areas to flow ultimately into South Australia to the advantage of South Australians and to electorates such as mine.

Electricity generation and demand for power is rising, I am told, at the rate of approximately five per cent per year. Most industries in Australia have an electricity power input cost ranging somewhere between five and 30 per cent. The efficient—and by the word `efficient' I do not mean solely economically efficient, I mean also environmentally efficient—generation of power is very important. It is very important to the nation, particularly in light of the present debate which is raging globally about the greenhouse effect and our responsibility.

In the bill before the House, what is proposed is the corporatisation of the Snowy Mountains authority and the legislation currently being considered by the Commonwealth is to complement legislation that has already passed the parliaments of New South Wales and Victoria. It was delayed in order to allow it to pass those state governments and then be complemented by the legislation we are considering.

This corporatisation runs counter to many of the policies pursued by the opposition and is an area in which there is a distinct policy difference between the opposition and the government. The government does not fear corporatisation. It recognises that ultimately the market will dominate the decisions we make. We may not like that and we may want to cushion some of those decisions in order to ensure that people who are disadvantaged are not going to be bruised by the dominance of the market but, ultimately, whether we like it or not, the market will dominate and all we can do is offer some cushioning for those who, as I said, may otherwise find themselves economically disadvantaged.

In the case of the market for power generation, we need to ensure that power is being generated in the most efficient way possible in Australia to meet the long‐term obligations we have to reduce the adverse effect of emissions that would increase the greenhouse effect. This legislation frankly allows room for the competition policy embraced by both sides of the parliament to be implemented in the area of power generation. What we are considering is the corporatisation of the Snowy scheme to allow competition policy to dominate the way in which power is generated and distributed across this nation.

Much of the concern about corporatisation expressed by the opposition is a concern I understand as a South Australian. Opposition parties in South Australia have expressed exactly the same concern. They expressed it about what was happening to the distribution of water, not power, in South Australia and the proposal by the South Australian government to corporatise the water distribution system within that state.

Wrongly, the image was created that South Australia's water distribution system was being corporatised simply to allow it to distribute profits at the expense of the users. The reality is that the corporatisation of water in South Australia has resulted in much more efficient water delivery. An asset owned by the people has not been sold—I must emphasise that point—but the capacity to distribute that facility has been corporatised.

I digress very briefly to use an appropriate illustration in the case of the corporatisation of water. It is like saying that the ownership of the pipes that bring the water to the shower still remains exactly where it was, but the taps are switched on and off by a corporate rather than a public identity, so the delivery of water is determined by those who efficiently manage those two taps.

In the case of this electricity distribution, what is proposed by the New South Wales, Victorian and Commonwealth governments—governments of both political persuasions—is the corporatisation of the Snowy Mountains power authority to ensure that the way the power is generated and the water is directed is done as efficiently as possible and that the management is under a corporate rather than a public authority. The major shareholders in this new corporate company will be New South Wales, Victoria and the Commonwealth. It is proposed, because of the location of the Snowy Mountains Authority, that the new company be incorporated in New South Wales.

I turn to where I began. I understand the superficial concerns expressed by the opposition and reflected in the amendment, but the simple view that in some way we can return the Snowy to its pristine state is nonsense. We are dependent on this river for the most efficient power generation in mainland Australia. Its management has never been better. The bill before the House allows that management to be sharpened even further through corporatisation. The management currently ensures not only that power is efficiently delivered but that water makes its way into the western states of Australia, particularly South Australia, and makes it way for uses in irrigation and South Australian industries, after that water has generated the power that eastern Australia so desperately needs.

The bill is about the efficient generation of that power and the fact that this national resource, having been used renewably to generate that power, then makes it way to my own state for irrigation distribution and for use as an irrigation supply. The irony is that we look at the efficient generation of power through this water system and fail to recognise that in the process we have also enhanced the environment of South Australia in water terms as well.

The irrigation areas of the Murrumbidgee represented here by the member for Riverina (Mr Hicks) and the irrigation areas of South Australia represented by me are largely dependent on Snowy water in order to ensure environmental flows into both the Murrumbidgee and the Riverland. Those additional flows have ensured that the water that is available to irrigators and domestic consumers is of better quality because of the management by the Snowy authority. This legislation ensures that both the water environment and the power environment will be more efficient.

There is a matter that I did overlook and that is that while the legislation has passed the lower house in New South Wales, it has not passed the upper chamber. I was conscious of that but did not emphasise it in my speech. However, the significant thing from my point of view is that here we have legislation for the efficient generation of power and effective environmental flows through both the Murrumbidgee and Riverland areas.

Those environmental flows determine how efficiently we can irrigate and it is, for me, a two-edged sword. This legislation allows us both to efficiently generate power and efficiently provide quality water into the electorates of the member for Riverina and myself. For that reason I support this legislation which complements what has already happened, or is happening, in New South Wales and Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) I will point out to him that under standing order 60, in view of his current infirmity, it is quite permissible for him to speak while seated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr, Duncan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you very much, Mr Deputy Speaker, and I will take advantage of your invitation. This legislation, the Snowy Hydro Corporatisation Bill 1997 and the Snowy Hydro Corporatisation (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997 , is important legislation. The principle of corporatisation of the Snowy Mountains Authority is not one with which the opposition has any difficulty. However, we do have a significant concern about the way in which the water resources of the Snowy scheme are allocated. I suspect it is a concern that is shared by government members because the bill proposes a mechanism where there will be an inquiry into appropriate allocations of the various flows that are necessary to sustain various users of those water flows.

SPEECH.PARA: The concerns that are no doubt common to landowners who require water for irrigation in various places are certainly going to be taken into account in a future inquiry, and the government has acknowledged that environmental flow is a significant issue that should be taken into account. However, the problem with this bill is that it takes a shoot first, ask questions afterwards approach. In other words, once we pass this bill the Commonwealth parliament effectively renounces any responsibility for what occurs thereafter. It plays no part in the appointment of the inquiry, it plays no part in assessing the validity of any conclusions reached by that inquiry, and it has no mechanism to intervene to ensure that national priorities are actually achieved.

Part of the national priorities that we believe this parliament must express is to ensure the environmental flows of the Snowy River itself. It has been said, and I think quite correctly, that the Snowy River is a national icon. I do not think there is any schoolchild in Australia who has not at one stage heard, if not to learned, the words of The Man from Snowy River. As well as that poem which has captured the imagination of generations of Australians, most people see the Snowy Mountains as an area of significant environmental importance and part of our national heritage. The idea that the river may be reduced to a trickle, and significant environmental impacts flow from that, is not one that Australians would entertain with any support at all.

We are not saying that the process is wrong. We are not saying that it is wrong to corporatise the authority which manages those water flows. We are not saying it is wrong to have an inquiry. We are saying it is wrong for the Commonwealth to step aside from any responsibility in the passage of this legislation before that inquiry reports and until we have a chance to see whether that inquiry has found in a way that we would support.

BREAK.PARA: There is no necessary reason to be troubled by the fact that the inquiry is to be established by the states rather than by the Commonwealth, but it is not unknown for inquiries to go off the rails. It is not appropriate for this Commonwealth to discharge its national responsibilities by saying that we will simply invest our faith in an inquiry of which we will not be involved in the form, the processes and the management, and which will not be responsible to the Commonwealth in any way, and of which the outcome is entirely unknown at this stage.

We are simply saying, `Let's hold the horses on this one; don't let them bolt down the ravine and crash down there with the sparks flying, until we know whether or not the inquiry does produce a result that we are comfortable with.' It probably will, and what is to be lost by insisting on that? A tragedy would be—and I think this government would find itself in a humiliating and awkward position—if as a result of an inquiry a perverse outcome is had and we are stuck with the situation where we have passed this legislation and yet the majority of the federal parliament, with national responsibilities, would be powerless to do anything about it. That would be a very poor outcome and not one that this opposition is going to be complicit in, in any way.

We have moved amendments which are simple in their intent. They do not really conflict with the objectives that the government is expressing. It is not the case that we have, as honourable members from the government side have been saying, a naive appreciation of this issue. It is not the case that we are suggesting that the Snowy River can run unbounded, as once it did before human intervention. But it is the case that we know that human intervention has had damaging environmental effects and that those damaging environmental effects have caused real community concern.

We want to make certain that we retain a role for the Commonwealth parliament so that we can look at the results of any inquiry. Included in the matters that the inquiry must take into account, as well as the distribution between various farm irrigators and other users of the water for commercial purposes, is that we want to make certain that the environment is not put at further risk and that we can do something to ensure that future generations of Australians are not left with a ditch through which a trickle runs: an environmentally degraded Snowy River.

The point is a simple one. It is puzzling that the government is standing on its dignity in relation to this matter. It would seem to me a convenience for the national parliament were we able to find an agreement that simply said that the corporatisation process was not one in which there was any political disagreement or any significant disagreement that there are competing and legitimate calls on the resources of the Snowy scheme. It is a river which has been dammed now for many years, over several generations. Invested in that were great engineering effort and tremendous national pride. We are not suggesting that that was wrong. Modern approaches might not go down that course but, at the time, it was an approach which was the source of great national pride and, as a result, many people have their livelihoods dependent on the diversion of some of those waters.

We are not suggesting that those issues should be ignored. We are saying that, at the end of this process, the inquiry may report in such a way that the commercial interests of a significant group of people who are dependent on that river may be placed at risk, or that, importantly—and I say this from my role as shadow minister for the environment—the environment and the flow of the Snowy itself are jeopardised in a way which the Australian community would regard as both unjustifiable and requiring the intervention of the Commonwealth parliament. If we pass this legislation, we will have basically handed away any reserve capacity to act on behalf of those who have a concern for the preservation of this river system, which we all hold to be so important as part of our natural heritage.

We should not be acting in this way. The suggestion that the Commonwealth parliament would dispose of its responsibilities in key areas, by passing them to an independent inquirer and then saying, `We wash our hands of any responsibility,' has never been a course that has been commended to the parliament. We normally resist those things; we should resist them now.

It certainly would be a great comfort to those Australians who believe that we ought to be able to protect future generations and ensure the viability of the Snowy River system that we do not set out on this course without the capacity of this parliament to later review any finding that, by some mischance, happens to give insufficient attention to those matters.

This is a proposal that has been moved by my colleague as shadow minister for resources and energy and one which we would hope would find support from the government. It does not conflict with their objectives, unless they are seeking to hide some base motive, and I do not attribute that to them in the least degree. I think we do share a common objective in this area, but that common objective could be derailed unless the Commonwealth parliament does retain that residual responsibility. To pass that up would be something that the Australian community will blame us for and hold us responsible for if we pursue a process where we wash our hands of responsibilities without knowing what the consequences are.

Unfortunately, the Bible leaves the greatest stain on those who take such courses—Pontius Pilate is remembered as the one who washed his hands. We have popular sayings of people who behave foolishly without knowing the consequences of their actions. We call it `buying pigs in pokes'. We talk about `shoot first; ask questions afterwards'. We have a whole range of expressions that sum up the wrong‐headedness of addressing an issue by establishing a process over which we have no control and then allowing the matter to go out of our hands and our judgment, and abdicating our national responsibility.

The mechanism in this bill is not one which we would support, although we support the objectives. We certainly would like to see this parliament maintain the responsibility that it should have for the future generations of all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Tony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in this debate in support of the Snowy Hydro Corporatisation Bill 1997 and the Snowy Hydro Corporatisation (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997 . It will afford me the opportunity to make some comments about the scheme and the major engineering achievement that it was, and then to discuss further what I think this country needs to get it moving economically, that is, to look at major capital works programs of a similar nature to the Snowy Mountains scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: The scheme itself was a major engineering achievement. It was far‐sighted, imaginative and innovative. I dare say it was one of the springboards to growth and prosperity in the fifties and sixties. It generated confidence, it generated jobs, it generated work for migrants who came to this country from all countries of the world, particularly from Europe, and it gave to this country a cultural identity which was enhanced enormously as a result of the migration of many of those people from foreign lands.

Those people, who were then called the `new Australians', have now become, with their children, part of the great Australian tradition of accepting people from overseas who have come here and worked damned hard to build Australia and make Australia great. That scheme itself is an absolute testament to the many migrant workers, as well as many Australians, who worked on it.

The genesis of the scheme derived from many proposals and suggestions during the first half of the 20th century. It culminated in definitive plans after World War II, and the Chifley government established the Snowy Mountains Hydro‐electric Authority. The constitutional validity for the establishment of such an authority was the exercise of the defence power at that time. Over the years, some doubt about that crept in and, ultimately, there needed to be joint Commonwealth‐state legislation which culminated in the Snowy Mountains Hydro‐electric Agreement Act 1958.

The scheme itself took 25 years to construct. It was one of the largest integrated water resource developments in the world, encompassing 16 major dams, seven power stations, 145 kilometres of interconnected tunnels and 80 kilometres of aqueducts. It is interesting to look at some other figures relating to the scheme: the scheme diverts the water of the Snowy River and its tributaries, which flow to the sea near Orbost in eastern Victoria, westward underneath the Snowy Mountains to augment the natural flows of the Murray River and the Tumut, which is a tributary of the Murrumbidgee River. It makes use of a total difference in altitude of some 800 metres between the main reservoirs and the power stations to the west.

It was interesting to hear the Chief Government Whip, the member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), talking about the effects it produced on his electorate. It is quite extraordinary that here is a development, which is in the seat of the honourable member for Eden‐Monaro (Mr Nairn) and almost down the road from the parliament, yet we have the Chief Government Whip saying that that has an effect in his electorate and also on the electorate of the member for Riverina (Mr Hicks). It is quite an amazing thing to contemplate.

But it did not stop there. In my view, the scheme had an effect across the whole of the country. As I have indicated, the scheme plays an important role in agricultural production, river management, flood mitigation, flood flow augmentation during drought and the control of salinity in the Murray and Murrumbidgee Rivers. Water has been diverted from other rivers such as the Snowy River. The community has started to question whether development of the Snowy scheme adequately acknowledged the impact of reduced flows in other rivers.

At the broader level, the Council of Australian Governments agreed to a process for water industry reform in Australia at its meeting on 11 April 1995. The comments of the member for Denison (Mr Kerr) about some of the aspects of the scheme looked at through 1997 eyes are probably fair. The development at that time was one that was certainly a great boost to Australia and one that was readily agreed to by all sides of politics. But it is true to say that there are some aspects on the environmental side of things that also have to be considered. With the benefit of time and with hindsight, it is obvious that some adjustments need to be made.

Nonetheless, what a fantastic scheme it is when you think of the enormity of the scheme with 25 years involved in completing it. When you think of the 100,000 people who were employed in the construction, they included tradesmen, labourers, engineers, draftsmen, drivers, fitters and turners, boilermakers, welders and people on the civil engineering side—all of those people were associated with it. It is an enormous thing to contemplate.

Then there were the support mechanisms that go with that employment such as the local businesses. But it spread even wider because there were little engineering shops, many miles away from the scheme itself, which turned up parts on their lathes, made tanks, welded boilers and constructed the turbine itself—all of those sorts of things. I am not sure that there were boilers there since it is hydro‐electric, but there were so many different aspects to it that the spread and the trickle‐down effect were quite incredible. Indeed, one can descend into metaphors here by thinking of the flow—metaphorically—the confidence that was generated by those turbines turning and the prosperity that was engendered.

We have had, of course, in Queensland, suggestions made over the years about the Bradfield scheme, a scheme that has never really got off the ground although it has been talked about for a long time. It involves a similar turning around of water back into inland Queensland—a major project when one sees in North Queensland so much water running into the sea.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think it will ever happen?

—We need the determination to look at these things and make them happen. The member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) has anticipated where I am travelling with this. It is those sorts of schemes that we have to look at, not only to stop this incredible drought cycle that we have all the time, but also to look at the confidence that can come with major capital works programs like this.

SPEECH.PARA: I am aware that the government will establish the Australian Federation Fund of $1 billion, but is this really enough in the great scheme of things? We have a major unemployment problem in my own electorate, particularly amongst youth. That occurs in a number of electorates, I know. It is a major problem for all members to grapple with and for governments to grapple with.

The government must seriously consider projects of a major scale that are open and that can stay with this country for many years. They can be part of the landscape and part of the revitalisation of Australia to remove the scourge of youth unemployment, and that of older people who are unemployed, by getting those people working in various occupations on the big projects that are there.

We have heard talk by Everald Compton about a Melbourne to Darwin railway. Things like this need to be discussed and looked at at this time. I am very much aware of the proposal for the employment of 100,000 people through a government scheme similar to the construction of the transcontinental railway from 1913 to 1917. There have been proposals about this and I think it is worthy to look at them, not dismiss them out of hand, because we do have a very serious situation in this country. Capital works did do the job for us, in my view, in the 1950s and 1960s when we had a time of great prosperity in this country.

It seems that virtually since the mid‐1970s this country really has not gone ahead to the extent it should have. There have been a lot of changes. There has been a technological revolution in so many areas. But still there are problems on the land with drought, with the attendant problems of unemployment and unskilled labourers who have nothing to do in so many areas.

With a project of the major capital type, perhaps we can do something about that. The suggestion of how it would work is something like this: the work would involve the provision of infrastructure throughout the country, meaning structures necessary for our everyday living and for increasing our population, including the basic supply of public facilities such as highways, bridges, streets, airports, water support, sewerage, electricity, et cetera.

Apart from 100,000 jobs, finance would flow to the Treasury. There would be a marked influence on business as well. The 100,000 people being unemployed costs the government $1.5 billion a year in unemployment payments. If all of these people were employed they would contribute $600 million in income tax, giving a net profit to the government of about $2 billion. In addition, the extra income from the 100,000 workers of about $700 million per annum would create a much greater demand for goods and services. As well, the larger projects would need support industries. In the long term there would be no shortage of available infrastructure to facilitate further national development.

In the time available it is not easy to go through these individual costings, but I will give an example. PAYE tax paid on an average of $28,000 is $6,000 per annum, leaving aside rebates and deductions. The net income of the employee would be $22,000 per annum. This compares with $15,000 presently paid to unemployed married workers. The estimated cost of employment of each worker would be generously calculated at: wage, $28,000; on‐cost, at 40 per cent, $11,200; and plant and material cost, at 20 per cent, $5,600—a total of $44,800 or, in round figures, $50,000.

At that rate the total annual cost of employing 100,000 workers would be $5 billion. Total borrowings over a 10‐year period would be $50 billion plus interest at one per cent. A 20‐year cost recovery period at five per cent per annum, which, in the case of each separate project, would begin on its transfer to the other contracting party—municipality, irrigation or road‐rail authority, state or federal department—would require an annual repayment of approximately $2.8 billion.

These figures are calculated within broad parameters, but it is important to note the effects of all of this. The absorption of 100,000 workers, mainly married breadwinners, into active employment of this type would relieve the federal budget of an unemployment expenditure of between $1 billion and $1½ billion per annum. As to the tax paid, as I mentioned before, 100,000 workers paying that average tax would contribute $600 million.

The purposes of the plan are confined to the necessity of making a direct attack on the unemployment problem. They do not remove the need to deal with the repayment of the foreign debt. The total extra income of 100,000 workers would thus amount to $700 million a year, resulting in a modest change from the present inflationary policy and thus providing a foundation of expanded demand for the products of both new and existing businesses.

It is important to consider proposals like this. The Snowy Mountains scheme would never have got off the ground but for far‐sighted and innovative policies and people of goodwill who saw the need both to increase Australia's population—to uplift its skill levels with skilled migrants and others who came to this country during the late 1940s, 1950s and 1960s to help augment the work force—and to look at the need that we have in this country to stabilise the drought cycle.

We do have to look at major capital works, in my view, to end this terrible drought‐wet cycle which is becoming more and more drought‐drought‐drought and very small wet. But if the water is being lost, as it has been over many years, and we have got the technology and the engineering expertise to change it, we have got to start looking seriously at these things. Unless we do that, we in this country will be selling out our young people, who, instead of being entitled to a future, will be bequeathed a debt. I support this legislation, but I ask the government to look at the building of major capital works in the years ahead and provide a vision for this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nairn, Gary, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure to speak on the Snowy Hydro Corporatisation Bill 1997 and the Snowy Hydro Corporatisation (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997 . As the member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith) commented, the Snowy scheme is very much within the electorate of Eden‐Monaro. It is predominantly within the electorate of Eden‐Monaro, although it has impact on a very large part of Australia, covering three states and a territory, the ACT.

SPEECH.PARA: The scheme is certainly one of the great engineering feats of this century. Many people would say today that, given some of the projects which have had great difficulty getting going in recent years, one may wonder whether, if the Snowy were being envisaged today, it would get off the ground. The vision that was shown by governments of the day to get it moving, back in the 1940s, was quite something.

Besides the terrific scheme and the impact that it has had on irrigation and power generation, the other thing about the Snowy scheme during its construction phase is that it has also had an enormous impact on Australia and on a variety of industries and professions. Cooma, in my electorate, is today probably one of the most multicultural towns in Australia. This is very much a result of the Snowy scheme and the people who were brought from all over the world because of their expertise in a variety of areas. Many of those people ended up back in Cooma. There are already several generations of those people. Cooma is a great example of a variety of backgrounds coming together and living in terrific harmony. In the year 1999, we will have the opportunity to celebrate that Snowy scheme. It started in 1949 and it will be 50 years old. Certainly one of the focuses of this celebration will be on that multicultural aspect.

This legislation comes about for the corporatisation of the Snowy. This is something that is really required for it to compete in a very rapidly changing electricity market, and I support that move wholeheartedly. If the Snowy scheme is to survive the long‐term future, this step has to be made.

The make-up of the Snowy is an interesting one. It is one that a lot of people do not understand in that it is the responsibility of three separate governments. The ownership involvement from the three separate governments is also often misunderstood or not known. It is described in the way the equity will be in the Snowy Hydro at the completion of the corporatisation—and that is, 13 per cent to the Commonwealth, 29 per cent to Victoria and 58 per cent to New South Wales. New South Wales has the greater part of the ownership of the ultimate corporatised body. Victoria has the second largest, with the Commonwealth only having 13 per cent. But the Commonwealth has the greater part of the debt and it is of great interest to the Commonwealth to move through this process for that reason as well as many other reasons.

At the completion of the corporatisation, the Snowy Hydro will assume the debt, which will be equivalent to the market value of the current agreed debt with the Commonwealth. So there is a negotiable amount there which the Commonwealth will have to agree to, as to the debt that the new entity will take over. They will take it over on the basis of an interim loan which will be for a term of six months. They will have six months to sort out their finances and ultimately repay that loan to the Commonwealth as soon as practical. That is what is in place in this legislation.

The other thing which is a matter of great debate is the issue of the water. One thing that needs to be understood is that the water will not be owned by the corporatised body. Some people have misunderstood that; they thought the actual water in the scheme will be owned by Snowy Hydro. That will not be the case. It will not be an asset of Snowy Hydro. There will be a licence with the New South Wales government for that water and that licence will be for an initial term of 75 years with a 50-year renewal option.

Some people have been concerned about that as well, that that term is too long and that it does not give safeguards. But the New South Wales legislation will add some safeguards with respect to that water licence. I understand that that legislation will have in it a requirement for frequent analysis and review of that licence, in particular in relation to environmental flows.

Then we come to the issue of environmental flows, which is probably the one contentious issue in this whole procedure. Going back quite some months before this legislation was put together, I think it was the view of the New South Wales government, the Victorian government and the Commonwealth that the corporatisation should proceed but there should be a mechanism, once the body was corporatised, to then go through a water inquiry process to see what changes should be made to the various flows.

I certainly made very strong representations to the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer) in relation to this, following many discussions I have had with people throughout my electorate particularly affected by the Snowy River itself. I was very pleased that the minister understood this problem and, in consultation with the New South Wales and Victorian governments, it was decided that a water inquiry will be conducted prior to the proclamation of the various pieces of legislation so that the actual flows that will be going into the various rivers, what water will be available for irrigation and what water will be available for power generation will be known.

That really had to occur because if you have a corporatised body they have to know what sort of assets they have got and where it will be going, rather than saying, `We're now corporatised, we've got this big debt,' only to find that a lot of asset might disappear as part of the inquiry. But a number of people were still not happy with that situation, and I think part of it comes from a misunderstanding of how the three pieces of legislation work. It was seen when the New South Wales legislation was introduced into the parliament of New South Wales some months ago that if that legislation was passed, then there was no real control about the water inquiry.

I guess it is a matter of trust. When you have three separate pieces of legislation from three separate governments and they are not all of the same political persuasion, which is relevant in this debate, there are certain safeguards there at the end of the day. I do understand the concerns that have been expressed by many of my constituents about ensuring that there are environmental flows in the Snowy River. Certainly the Snowy River is an icon in Australia, it is certainly an icon in my electorate, and I want to make sure that the appropriate decisions are made.

There has been a variety of studies that have taken place. There was a scoping study which was conducted by the New South Wales Department of Land and Water Conservation, the Victorian Department of Conservation and Natural Resources and the Snowy Mountains Hydro‐electric Authority. That scoping study unfortunately has never been made public; publicly we are really unaware of the exact outcome.

There has been another study done by the scientific world which came up with a percentage flow that would be required for the Snowy of something in the order of 28 per cent of its original flows. Currently, the flow into the Snowy is probably about one per cent of the original river flows. The agreement that is there at the moment sees something like about 25 megalitres of water a day released from the Jindabyne Dam.

BREAK.PARA: I was reasonably comfortable with the way in which the legislation was put together between the three states and the safeguards there were to ensure that the correct decision was made out of the water inquiry before proclamation. It has fallen off the rails, I guess, to some extent inasmuch as the New South Wales legislation did not go through. The New South Wales legislation was to be used as the mechanism to start the water inquiry. It concerns me that that legislation did not pass and therefore the water inquiry has not got under way. I do not want to see a situation occur in which, because of other pressures, we might be faced with pressure on the two states and the Commonwealth to pass this legislation without the appropriate work being done.

I know the New South Wales legislation is going back into the New South Wales parliament. I do not know the timing of that and what might occur as a result—whether it will pass or not—but it is something that I will be watching closely. Perhaps there is a role for the Commonwealth here—and I am not sure at this very moment of the legalities of doing this—to somehow get this water inquiry going. Somehow or other, either at the Commonwealth level or the state level, the water inquiry needs to start. I will watch closely what happens in New South Wales and then discuss it with the minister to see whether we can assist in any way.

Another aspect of this bill that will be sorted out as part of the corporatisation is the supply of water to a number of small villages in my electorate. Currently a variety of small villages in the Snowy River Shire take water from the system. There is nothing formal in place—one could say that it is almost an ad hoc arrangement—but quite a number of villages rely very heavily for their water supply on the Snowy scheme. The corporatisation will formalise that and give security but it does concern the Snowy River Shire that they do not have that security at the moment.

I might foreshadow here that if we have any further great delay in this legislation, either at a federal level or through the states, I will consider introducing a private member's bill to give that security of water supply in the interim. It would be a sunset situation: once this corporatisation is completed, it would lapse. There is certainly considerable concern amongst many of the small villages that they might get caught up in the wrangling between the states and the Commonwealth and they would like to see that security. It would be a very simple matter to provide that security now and it would finish as a piece of legislation once the corporatisation is completed.
I will be looking at that. Once again, it will depend on the likelihood of the New South Wales legislation passing and the water inquiry getting under way.

In conclusion, I am in support of this legislation with the various qualifications that I have mentioned. It sounds like throwing balls up in the air and not being sure which one to catch first. When you are dealing with a very complex issue like this, where there are two states and the Commonwealth involved, it is inevitable that that will occur. The Snowy scheme requires this legislation to be an efficient and competitive entity in the electricity market for the future. It produces excellent electricity in the overall scope of things, particularly so far as greenhouse gases are concerned. Hydro-electricity is the most efficient in that respect and I think we have a great system that can possibly be developed even further in the years to come under a corporatised body.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks, Noel, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the Snowy Hydro Corporatisation Bill 1997, which lays the foundation for the creation of a financially viable entity to operate on a competitive mutual basis and to participate in the emerging national electricity market. It is important to recognise that this bill, which creates the company Snowy Hydro Ltd, and transfers current assets and liabilities, is the result of an agreement between the Commonwealth, New South Wales and Victorian governments.

SPEECH.PARA: While welcoming the bill, I must say that many of my constituents in the Murrumbidgee and Coleambally irrigation areas had some reservations about the proposal and I will refer to a number of those concerns. As the other speakers have said, the Snowy Mountains Hydro‐Electric Scheme played a significant role in the development of Australia as a nation and is regarded as a national icon. Its construction, at a cost of $1 billion, represented a massive investment for Australia in the postwar era. Today it is recognised as one of the truly great engineering feats of the modern world.

The project brought together 100,000 workers from 30 countries, the vast majority of them being migrants wanting to carve out a new life for themselves in Australia following the end of the Second World War. In fact, my next‐door neighbour in Griffith for many years, Marco Visentin, an Australian of Italian heritage, worked on the scheme, sometimes up to his armpits in nearly freezing water. The friendships he made on the scheme nearly 50 years ago still endure, as does his love of trout fishing in the streams of the Snowy Mountains.

The scheme is widely recognised as the birthplace of multiculturalism in Australia. Construction started in 1949 and was completed 25 years later, collecting almost all of the water which previously flowed down the Snowy River on the eastern side of the Great Dividing Range. The scheme was designed to divert the flow westwards into the Murray‐Darling Basin to the irrigation areas along the Murray and Murrumbidgee rivers to provide essential drought security to the vast dry inland of south‐eastern Australia. The Snowy, with its network of 16 major dams with a storage capacity 13 times the volume of Sydney Harbour, power stations, tunnels and aqueducts, became a major electricity generator in mainland Australia.

The corporatisation of the Snowy Mountains Hydro‐Electric Scheme has been a complex issue, but the commitment to corporatisation has remained constant despite changes of governments. Although there is general commitment to corporatisation, the Murrumbidgee Valley Water Users Association in my electorate of Riverina has some concerns about the future cost of water under the new arrangement and any cuts in flows along the river systems.

The users association is an organisation involving delegates from 12 local government areas, the Lowbidgee League and Great Southern Energy. It takes in the federal electorates of Riverina, Farrer and Hume. It was formed in 1939 to promote the development of the valley through the economical and sustainable use of water. One of its first undertakings was to promote the Snowy Mountains scheme and the diversion of water to the dry inland. One gentleman who was at meetings where the scheme was proposed, and who is still a member of the Murrumbidgee Valley Water Users Association, is Councillor Bill Blacker of Leeton Shire.

This visionary project has provided the incredible economic development within the region and resulted in the development of one of Australia's major food bowls. While the Murray Valley Water Users Association has no objection to corporatisation, it is most concerned to ensure that the water continues to be diverted westward at no cost to the irrigation authorities for the continued sustainable production of food. This concern has been the subject of ongoing representation to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson). As recently as August, a delegation from the water users association met with the minister's representative to air their concerns.

The Snowy Mountains Authority was originally established to generate electricity and to supply water to downstream users at no cost. The water users argued that this arrangement must continue in perpetuity and be built into any agreement of sale. Water users want any agreement of sale to enshrine the right of extractive users to access the water released by the Snowy Mountains Authority free of charge to the relevant water distribution authority, whether that be the government, state operated corporations or some subsequently privatised authority.

The organisation believes strategic releases of water are vital to improve the health of inland rivers, and certainly the Murrumbidgee River has its share of problems. Controlled water flows are essential in combating problems such as the decline in native fish numbers, the decline in wetlands, algal blooms which are caused by soil erosion and stream bank erosion and the European carp infestation.

One of the most pressing problems for the Murrumbidgee River is the control of salinity. This is mainly dry land salinity as little irrigation drainage finds its way back into the river. This requires a flushing of the system at various times and is mostly provided for by the normal irrigation flows and periods of high river flow. I am pleased, therefore, to see within the bill under `Water rights' that:
Water will not be an asset of Snowy Hydro. The existing rights of the Scheme with respect to water will be continued under a licence granted by the appropriate NSW water authority.

The water licence will be in respect of an agreed geographical area; specify Snowy Hydro's right to use, collect, divert, store and release the water; provide that the Snowy Hydro's water rights are subject to the rights of certain water users to extract up to a total of three gigalitres per annum from within the area; be for an initial term of 75 years with a 50-year renewal option; and be capable of amendment by the appropriate New South Wales water authority through an agreed process.

Financial consideration will also be provided to Snowy Hydro by New South Wales if such amendments have an adverse material financial impact on the company. Apart from fees under the water licence, no other charges will be imposed on Snowy Hydro in relation to water.

I also note that in relation to water releases the water licence will set out Snowy Hydro's water release obligations. Unless otherwise agreed, those water release obligations will be consistent with the existing arrangements governing the scheme. In any case they will: protect Victoria's existing right to a share of inflows into the scheme; protect South Australia's existing rights, and the member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) previously said something about that; prescribe minimum release volumes in time of drought; provide for variations in releases in emergency situations; include provisions for consultation between Snowy Hydro and the relevant water authorities; and provide for the outcomes of the water inquiry.

Presently, there are many rapid changes taking place in relation to the care and control of waterways throughout Australia as communities and authorities work to overcome problems that have developed over many years and ensure the long-term viability of a water system which, in the case of the Murray‐Darling system, supports many people, towns, cities and industries.

While the rehabilitation of the Murray-Darling Basin river system is essential, any moves made to change the water usage patterns on the system should be based on scientific fact and not on the perceptions and/or rantings of the uninformed and the verbose.

BREAK.PARA: If governments wish to have communities, particularly those based on irrigation, work in partnership with them then they must present facts to those people and not theories that are not subject to intellectual academic rigour. In this way there will be cooperation between governments, the bureaucracy and an irrigation community that believes in sustainable agriculture and cares for the environment.

The recent imposition of caps on water usage for irrigators is a case in point. Water users question the imposition of caps on the release of water from the Snowy Mountains and argue the cap system will not benefit the environment but will cause considerable economic loss to the Murrumbidgee valley and the nation.

The Murrumbidgee Valley Water Users Association is pressing the federal government not to implement a permanent cap on diversions but rather to take measures to ensure the real environmental problems be addressed on a valley by valley basis to ensure the future health of our rivers. The association wants the government to take urgent measures to instigate research into the control of European carp and urges the New South Wales government to remove any restrictions on the use of responsible electrical stunning of fish to harvest European carp. The association wants the New South Wales government to implement sound, scientifically based management practices in conjunction with the proposed river catchment committees.

In relation to the European carp problem, these fish stir up the sediments on the bottom of the river and remove natural vegetation which acts as a sink for nutrients, and they feed on the Daphne flea which eat the blue-green algae. The control of carp is of prime and urgent importance to the health of our rivers and without that control all other measures will have little impact.

It is worth noting that a factory turning carp into fertiliser has been an outstanding success but cannot operate in New South Wales waters because the proprietors are not allowed to operate an electric stunning device on a permanent basis. The harvesting of carp may not be the permanent answer but it will provide a more effective control than is presently available.

It is also worth noting that if a virus for carp control was released, with carp at their present numbers, the numbers of carp deaths would use up all available oxygen when the carp decomposed, possibly causing a massive kill off of native fish. Therefore, it is essential to reduce the numbers of carp before implementing any biological control.

Whilst speaking on the corporatisation of the Snowy Mountains scheme, there is a matter relating to water quality that I would like placed on record. I believe the CSIRO, working with the Griffith City Council, has found a way to reduce to a minimum the phosphates and nitrates that are present in sewage.

In conjunction with the CSIRO, the Griffith City Council has embarked on a major trial over the last three years or so to test a system called `Filter'. This process is aimed at reducing to a minimum, and EPA acceptable levels, the amount of phosphorus and sewage effluent. As you would be aware, these nutrients are the major cause of algal blooms in receival waters.

`Filter' is an exciting but simple agricultural solution to an urban problem and has national and international potential which is being explored. The trial has been in progress at the Griffith sewage treatment site and has proved extremely successful. To date approximately $1 million has been expended. The land and water resources department and the Environmental Planning Authority have been closely consulted on the project. The council is now gearing up for a full size pilot of approximately 15 hectares of the `Filter' scheme, to prove its commercial viability. Once trialled at this scale, the aim is to construct another 100 hectares to treat the entire effluent produced by Griffith and its connected villages.

Council has applied for Natural Heritage Trust moneys to assist in this project through the urban water directorate and land and water conservation. It is to be hoped that money can be obtained through the Natural Heritage Trust, or elsewhere, to continue this work, which not only has local benefits but could have tremendous potential both nationally and internationally.

I would especially like to place on record the work done by Dr John Blackwell and his team at the CSIRO in Griffith on this project. While on the subject of the CSIRO, I would remind the House of the establishment of a national centre for irrigation science in Griffith. This has been confirmed by the CSIRO land and water chief, Dr Graham Harris, on more than one occasion. The establishment of this institute will involve a close partnership between the CSIRO, the Charles Sturt University in Wagga Wagga and all centres carrying out irrigation research. The establishment of a chair of irrigation sciences at Wagga Wagga campus of the CSU, with Wayne Meyer as founding professor, was a vital element of this proposal.

Despite the failure of the legislation to pass the New South Wales upper house, it was the intention of this legislation, prior to proclamation in full of any corporatisation legislation of the states, to sponsor a public inquiry into environment issues arising out of the current pattern of water flows caused by the operation of the scheme, in accordance with the agreed terms of reference. The inquiry will submit to the states comprehensive, costed options to address the issues considered by the inquiry within six months of its commencement. Thereafter, the states will consider the final report of the inquiry and agree upon a final outcome within two months or such other time as may be agreed by them.

I repeat that any inquiry or inquiries by the federal and state governments will need to be carried out with intellectual and academic vigour, and to consider the consultative input of all water user groups to make use of the water for the Snowy Mountains scheme. Only in this way will the best interests of the nation be served.
Motion (by Mr Sawford)—agreed to:
That further proceedings on these bills be conducted in the House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 October, on motion by Mr Slipper:
That the House take note of the paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the report on aspects of youth suicide, which arose from the seminar of the Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs, it is very disturbing to note that in Australia we have such a high youth suicide rate. A quarter of young male deaths in 1995, I think it was, could be attributed to youth suicide, and 17 per cent of young females, similarly. This, of course, is only a small proportion of youth suicide attempts that have been made. We know that at least 10 hospitalised attempts are made for every successful attempt that is undertaken. We know that many suicide attempts are made beyond those which do not result in hospitalisation. We know that the figures have increased over time and we know that the Australian youth suicide is higher than in the United States of America, New Zealand and many European countries.

BREAK.PARA: Prior to becoming a parliamentarian, some time ago, I was a youth worker and worked with street kids in youth refuges and the like. My observation in that time, in working with many young people who endeavoured to take their own lives, or engaged in risk‐taking behaviours, was that there is no single cause, no single factor, that I could observe amongst the various young people that I worked with.

There was a multitude of factors—sometimes single factors, sometimes a combination of them—at play when a young person was engaged in risk‐taking behaviour, or when they actually physically endeavoured to take their life and unfortunately, sometimes, succeeded. With things like early intervention strategies, safe and affordable housing to escape abusive situations, and access to help and support, quite often young people were able to turn their lives around.

The sadly curious factor of youth suicide in Australia is the disturbingly high proportion of young men, particularly from the bush, who endeavour to take—and succeed in taking—their own lives. I think there are quite a few factors at play here. In my experience, these are often issues of sexuality, abuse in childhood, institutionalisation, unemployment, substance use and the implications that that brings with the involvement of the criminal justice system, and the interaction of the criminal justice system and young people themselves.

Sometimes they are issues of race; sometimes they are the lack of skills—whether it is literacy or general life skills—sometimes they are issues of transportation, a sense of isolation; sometimes there are changes to things like social security and income support mechanisms that young people desperately need. Quite often, there is a sense of being scapegoated, where young people are essentially blamed for the circumstances which they quite often find themselves in as a consequence of societal dysfunction.

I do not believe that we should turn the heat up further on Australia's young people by scapegoating them for things like high unemployment. Of course there are more young people than there are jobs going, and the temptation occasionally for policy makers is to blame, or scapegoat, the people who find themselves in the circumstance of trying to find work, rather than to actively support them to progress their lives.

I do not think it is helpful in this debate to push particular ideological wheelbarrows and to try to use this extremely disturbing and unhappy aspect of our society to justify changes which are fundamentally ideologically driven. We have to take a very broad and open‐minded approach to the issue of youth suicide.

I have noted that earlier speakers have referred to some observations that have been made about a correlation between religious participation in Australia and young people's suicide endeavours and various trends. I think that issue is a bit of an oversimplification. Sometimes, factors which manifest themselves as an outcome cannot necessarily be seen as a cause of young people seeking to take their own lives.

In the time remaining to me, I would like to talk a little about this concept of reciprocal obligation, because this government in particular has talked a lot about reciprocal obligation. It has consistently demanded of young people that they reciprocate an obligation back to society for things which we, as a fair society, believe they should be able to receive, such as income support.

I would like to examine the reciprocal obligation of the government back to young people themselves. We demand of young people that they be available, for example, for employment, or education, if it is available. We demand of them that they observe the laws of this parliament. What perhaps young people should be seeking is a reciprocal obligation from the parliament itself to themselves for essentially a social contract that part of its endeavour is to eliminate the causes of youth suicide, devising a system of, for example, social welfare which does not seek to scapegoat or blame young people for the shortcomings of our society but seeks to assist them to overcome disadvantages that they may find within it.

This contract needs to guarantee to young people that we, as elected members, work to ensure that they are protected from exploitation, have access to affordable housing, have access to real jobs and training opportunities, have access to intervention mechanisms if they are necessary to stop young people who are at risk from committing suicide—access to the sorts of things which often the young people that I worked with as a youth worker did not have access to. That kind of social contract with young people needs to ensure that the causes of youth suicide are eliminated from society.

In this debate, as I have said, we do not want to be overly simplistic. We do not really need to bring a whole range of prejudices to this debate; we need to be open‐minded about it. We need to pledge ourselves to eliminate division and disharmony from our community. With the government insisting that young people uphold their part of the social contract in order to access the social welfare system, we, as parliamentarians, need to ensure that we uphold our part of that contract.

A lot of speeches have been made in this place and elsewhere about seeking specific obligations from young people themselves to the community. It mystifies me why we, as parliamentarians, cannot make specific obligations back to them. Most notable, of course, is a specific undertaking that we will reduce youth unemployment, for example, or increase employment and training opportunities by a specified target. When you are a young person and you are without accommodation, when you have come from an abusive family, when you have come into contact with the criminal justice system at an early age, when you have worked on the streets, when you have got difficulties with literacy and numeracy, when you may have substance issues, when you may be the subject of a fair amount of abuse because of your sexuality or what have you, when you may be isolated because of lack of transport in the bush, when you may have difficulties in obtaining just basic income support, when you do not have a lot of hope, it is a reasonable ask of this parliament that it makes a specific undertaking to those young people and it reciprocates the obligation which it so often demands of young people themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I would like to acknowledge the work that the Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs have done in the preparation of this report and the national forum on youth suicide held earlier this year. I would also like to make a few points however in relation to the community, particularly in my electorate of Herbert.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier this year, I tried to get information relating to the incidence of suicide on Palm Island. Palm Island is a deed of grant in trust island under the Queensland Aboriginal affairs act which lies about 40 kilometres off the coast of Townsville. It is quite a large island and it is in the electorate of Herbert.

The first thing I discovered when I tried to get information and accurate details on the incidence of youth suicide on Palm Island was that indeed it was very difficult. I and my staff were shuffled from one person to another and from one government body to another. I am concerned that suicide, and particularly youth suicide, in communities such as Palm Island is in danger of developing the point of view `Out of sight, out of mind'. It is very concerning indeed.

When someone is murdered on Palm Island then the media reports it, but rarely, if at all, does the media report the incidence of suicide attempts, and those suicide attempts at this stage are running at about one every four weeks on the island. I do not want to appear to be lumping the problem on the backs of the media only, but if the information is not there for the media or any other member of the public to access then how are they going to be able to report on it?

I believe a system of accurate reporting and recording of the incidence of suicide, and youth suicide in particular, should be introduced—a system that takes into consideration attempted suicide. I would like to think that one already exists. After all, we seem to be able to assess national and state statistics. But after the trouble I have had in trying to gather local information relating to Palm Island, I have to ask the question: is the system of reporting really good enough?

After talking to the Palm Island Aboriginal Council and the state health department earlier this year, I learnt that on Palm Island there had been two suicide deaths and a further 12 suicide attempts since the beginning of the year. Since then a few months have passed and so I expect that the number would have increased. In the 1996 calendar year there were six hangings resulting in deaths; between August and December 1996 there were a further three suicide attempts. While I believe these reported statistics to be accurate, I am still waiting for formal confirmation.

Clearly, there are some major problems on Palm Island crossing a variety of areas such as employment, education, access to health and welfare services, and isolation. While I know that we as a government have made tremendous steps in addressing suicide as an issue, I am concerned that the action we have been taking could prove ineffective on Palm Island.

The government has focused a lot of effort on the provision of telephone crisis counselling services, and rightly so. I have a close association with, for example, Lifeline in Townsville and their director, the Reverend Ev Blackman. I know the work they do in telephone counselling and that it saves lives on a daily basis. However, earlier this year I tried to phone the Palm Island Aboriginal Council to make appointments for constituent visits. For more than a day, phone and fax services to the island were not available due to Telstra cabling faults. Suicide simply does not wait for phone services to be restored.

Access to public phones on Palm Island is very limited indeed. There is only one reliable public phone, located in a retail store on the island, but it cannot be accessed outside normal business hours. The three public phones outside the post office are all out of order as a result of vandalism. There are only 259 phone services on Palm Island, the vast majority of which are private phones. These phones service a population of about 4,000.

I am concerned also that telephone crisis counselling services may not be culturally appropriate to addressing the needs of the Palm Island Aboriginal community. The Palm Island Council has expressed concern that, as well as not having ready access to phones on the island, people would not want to talk to a total stranger over the phone. It is just the cultural appropriateness aspect.

Palm Island Women's Centre coordinator Delena Foster believes the community needs more counsellors on the island so that face‐to‐face counselling sessions can be conducted. Another suggestion is that a youth conference be organised so that the young people can sit down together, discuss the issue of youth suicide and look at possible solutions to address the problem.

I am pleased to report to the House that the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) has announced that former senator Neville Bonner is going to go to the island to spend a considerable period of time assessing what he sees are the needs and demands of that island community. Ex‐senator Bonner is a very experienced person, a person who has already lived on Palm Island and has family on Palm Island. I believe that the report that Neville Bonner will produce for the minister will be very valuable indeed in directing where government resources should be best targeted to meet the needs of the Palm Island community. I am looking forward to that visit and that report from Neville Bonner when he moves to Palm Island in the near future.

PARA.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—
Sitting suspended from 11.35 a.m. to 11.45 a.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, before the division I was telling the House that the government had decided to appoint former senator Neville Bonner to go to Palm Island and to report back to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs in relation to the needs of the island and how the government might best address those needs. One of those needs will concern the youth suicide element. In meeting with the Palm Island Council last week, there was certainly a very great concern amongst the councillors for the young people of Palm Island and how they might stop this terrible situation happening on the island with the suicide and the attempted suicides.

SPEECH.PARA: As I am advised, there are two principal contributing factors to youth suicide. One of those is the standard of education and the other is the status of employment of the person concerned. I am very pleased to report to the House that unemployment in the Townsville region continues to fall. In the first 18 months of the new government, unemployment has fallen from 10.1 per cent down to now about 5.9 per cent. It is a very good result for Townsville and a very good result for the region. That in some way addresses the situation in relation to the unemployment aspect of youth suicide. Certainly with Townsville becoming the fastest growing regional area in the country, I expect unemployment to continue to fall in our city. With the prospects that are there and what I know of the development of our community I believe that the city is going to go further in that direction.

During Senator Herron's visit to Palm Island last week, Mr Deputy Speaker, there was a long discussion with the Aboriginal council. The chairperson of the council, Councillor Pina Geia, and also a young councillor, Robert Blackley, were most keen to impress upon the minister the need to look at how that community is operating and how best the government might help them. One of the interesting results of that meeting was that it was not a question of, `Mr Minister, please give us more money'; it was a question of `We would like to help ourselves.' It is tremendously refreshing in an Aboriginal community to see that kind of response coming from an Aboriginal council. I take my hat off to the council for being proactive and for certainly being concerned about the terrible conditions on the island.

As a quick aside, Mr Deputy Speaker, I think that this country has condemned the Aboriginal community to a life of poverty and welfare dependence. The sooner we get them off that cycle the better, and certainly that is the feeling in the Palm Island Aboriginal community.

BREAK.PARA: Tackling youth suicide on Palm Island, or indeed in other regional and remote North Queensland communities, should involve everyone. The government has a direct responsibility to play a hand in this battle but so does the community. I recognise that the problem of youth suicide cannot be fixed overnight. It is a long‐term problem and it needs to be attacked year after year in a coordinated manner, across a variety of social and economic fields. I am pleased that the issue of youth suicide is being tackled in a very much bipartisan way, as it should be. Certainly the previously speaker, the member for Fraser (Mr Dargavel) referred to that and I support him in his suggestions. There are some issues which are just too important to be buried in party politics, and youth suicide is one of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron, Eoin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The presentation of this report of the Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs could not have come too soon. Suicide, and particularly suicide by young people, is a tragedy that it is difficult for many of us to comprehend. Unfortunately, in Australia it is a tragedy that occurs too often. Members would be aware that Australia has one of the highest rates of youth suicide in the industrialised world. I am glad the committee has taken up this issue and did not put it on the backburner.

SPEECH.PARA: For the record, on 27 September in 1993, I wrote to then chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs urging the committee to instigate an inquiry into suicide with particular emphasis on suicides amongst young people. Unfortunately, that was not taken up. I reinforced my call for an inquiry into youth suicide on 3 February in 1994, in a speech to the House of Representatives. Suffice to say, nothing eventuated. I do not intend that to be taken as a reflection on the former committee, but it was an issue I thought was needing desperately to be investigated.

Suicide is a topic people find difficult to discuss. Indeed, it is often considered taboo to talk about. However, brushing it aside will not help us address the problem and look for solutions, if there are solutions. By discussing suicide and the fact that there is help—and that suicide is not an alternative—we may help someone contemplating taking their own life to talk about their problem.

In the 10 years to 1995, in my own home state of Western Australia, there were 434 suicides by young people: 338 in urban areas and 96 in rural areas. It is now too late to ask those young people, who were in the prime of their lives, why they did not wish to continue living. We lost 434 Western Australians in that one year who should still be with us today.

Suicide is a difficult policy issue to address. How do we as, policy makers and law makers, make decisions to prevent suicide. Obviously, the reasons why someone decides to take their life are many and varied. Is it possible for a government to prevent all of these suicides, or even some of them? Of course, that is a question that cannot be properly answered.

I note the first recommendation of the committee is that a national advisory council on youth suicide prevention be established to provide strategic advice to the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) on youth suicide prevention and related matters. It is suggested that this council would provide policy advice at the very highest level.

My personal observation is that the participants on that committee, or the people who should be consulted, are those most vulnerable—young people. The young people involved should not just be those with a good education or from professional sectors of the work force or high profile young people. It should include young unemployed people, young people with disabilities, and others who have been recognised as in the high risk areas. Let them give their perspective on policies which may help prevent suicide and also on policies which may unfortunately contribute to suicide.

We need to do all we can to prevent suicide. With most deaths, families and friends know that they are blameless. However, with suicide, family and friends of someone who takes their life feel guilty for what has occurred. They do take the blame. They ask that big question: why? What should I have done to stop this? A question we, as policy makers, should also be asking is: what can we do to prevent suicide?

I know that I cannot answer that question. This report will hopefully be the first step in providing those answers. Rather than offering my thoughts any further, I would like to read to the chamber part of an essay from Catherine Whisson, a young Western Australian delegate to the Australian Youth Forum which took place here in Canberra earlier this year. I thought is something worth taking in because she and her peers are representative of the people that we are talking about here today, and the people that we are trying to help. She wrote:

I was fortunate to have a loving family and friends to help through some dark times. When I was diagnosed with Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS) I felt alone. CFS is a little known debilitating illness causing social, physical and emotional problems. My whole life went through upheaval as I tried to cope on my own in the city, after a recent move from Busselton for study and employment.
It wasn't until I felt there was hope for the future that I began to take control of my life again and regain my confidence to `Seize the day'.

Young people also need to know there's hope. They need to know they are precious, that reality can be better than fantasies built by drug highs and short lived sexual gratification.
