That they can be loved for who they are. Lack of confidence and lack of self esteem are killing our young people. We need to address the root of the problems, as well as their side effects, before it's too late.

I've found my music and songwriting is a valuable and effective tool in breaking down barriers, touching people and uniting them. Australia can take advantage of this process by utilising the arts, theatres, sporting facilities, landscape, and the atmosphere that is unique to each area in encouraging young people to better their talents to try new skills. It's not just about finding something for a young person to do to fill their time, it's
about creating an environment that is challenging and inspirational, while allowing young people to meet with others and establish a network of friends.

The ideas that I want to take to Canberra for discussion have come from personal experience, growing in the isolation of the country. I also want to take other people's thoughts, opinions and life experiences, so I have spent considerable time with a broad range of young people from around Perth and country areas. Some of their concerns and desires for them as young people are included.

I passionately believe that young people need encouragement and understanding in their family, school and community environments. Increased esteem among young people builds confidence and stops the onset of the tragedies that plague many of Australia's youth.

Suicide is rapidly increasing in our society today. Young people are finding too much stress placed on them through relationships, study, employment, and they feel that there is nowhere to turn. Most young people contemplating suicide just want attention and need someone to take some time with them.

People that have experienced the pain of going through various tragedies such as drug abuse, attempted suicide, prison and loss of a loved one should be encouraged to share their insight. Many people find they go through rehabilitation only to return to the community still lacking a sense of direction. Without necessary support, friendship and encouragement they may return to their old ways. Our community can support these people with inclusion in projects that enhance their esteem. Young people can relate to what they view as `real people with real problems' and so these people give hope to the prevention of these pressing issues.

It is a symptom of young people feeling worthless, not a complete person, like someone who has nothing to give to society. It is a hopelessness where no‐one can hear the silent cries. Despair can be a place like the black hole without compassion or understanding.

We need to utilise projects that will benefit our community, projects that will create an atmosphere that will give young people hands‐on experience, creativity, and allow them to `let off steam' through positive mediums such as sculpture, product design in furniture, coffee shops, landscaping, sports programs, music, theatre and arts. One‐on‐one friendships and support networks are nurtured through those activities.

A suggestion is to base it at a house where young people are free to come any time, free to talk confidentially, and encouraged to spread their wings. This house will provide security and readily available information and help on issues ranging from health, education and employment, et cetera, in a non‐threatening manner. Professional people, for example, doctors and nurses and counsellors and so on, will be encouraged to come and speak at workshops to young people, parents and the caring community. Projects listed above would operate from this house, going out into the community.

Volunteers would need to be someone that youth could relate to, be on the same level, trustworthy, caring, passionate and empathetic, good listeners, and make a difference. A mobile unit of people having these qualities, for example, doctors, counsellors, compassionate young people, well-known citizens and identities, would go out to suburbs and rural areas enthusing and implementing projects, et cetera.

Every individual is unique no matter the past, the background, the future, your family, your finance, your intelligence or your capabilities. You're you! So be you! You can make it even when you are left on your own or people do not put their trust in you. Stand up, be tall, encourage and lift up the person next to you. Standing hand in hand, you can make it. You are precious, with qualities the next person does not have. Like a body, each part plays an important role. Without one, life would die.

As you can see from the comments by the young people I have interviewed or who have contacted me, they have firm, rational and worthwhile ideas to improve their own futures. It is the responsibility of the leaders of our nation to respond in a serious and sensitive manner.
I commend Catherine on her essay and for her maturity and youth. It is those views we need to take in and listen to when addressing this most important issue. I commend the committee for its work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis, Colin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the members of the Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs who organised this topical and important seminar. Australia has the fourth highest rate of male suicide in the developed world according to news reports out recently. Why are so many Australians committing suicide? All of us in this parliament have a firm belief that our youth is Australia's future. We are all here, irrespective of our political colours, to make a contribution towards helping our political, social and economic institutions progress, and to help leave Australia a better place, even if only slightly better, than we inherited from those who went before us.

SPEECH.PARA: A recent book by Bronwyn Donaghy, Leaving Early, analysed many case studies of suicide and found that the key factors in Australian male suicide are isolation and fear of difference. There are higher suicide rates than usual in many country towns; the presence of guns seems to be an added factor. When men attempt suicide, they usually succeed. I cannot but think that we are to some extent failing Australia's youth and, in so doing, robbing Australia of her future.

Youth suicide, or, indeed, suicide by whatever demographic group in whatever location and by whichever method, is all too prevalent in Australia. It is a tragic final solution to life. For youth, it has become a convenient final escape from their place in society. For those they have left behind, it is a closed window of mystery, distress, grief and a longing search for an answer. All of us in this parliament, I suspect, have come at some stage face to face with suicide, be it in our own associations or through contact with many people who walk in through our office doors, write to us or telephone us.

A few weeks back, the Illawarra Mercury published a two‐page spread headed, `Bundanoon, a town in mourning'. Bundanoon is a beautiful small town located in the Southern Highlands, a stone's throw from my coastal electorate, and it is a place that I used to represent. The population is just 1,800 and five men have killed themselves within the past four weeks. The men ranged in age from 19 to 77. All were known to one another; two were best mates who suicided just 11 days apart.

An Anglican minister, the Reverend Wayne Tidsley, with the support of community groups like Lifeline and the Rose Foundation, along with Wingecarribie Shire Council, called together the community to ask why, to try to discover the answers to how more incidents could be prevented and to comfort those who had lost their loved ones. The Illawarra Mercury reported:

The youngest victim, 19, had a secure life and a bright future. He was nothing like the stereotypical young suicide victim. He was working with his dad in the family tree‐clearing business and he was popular. He had prospects, money in the bank, and the support of his mum, dad, and older sister, but none of that was in his mind on August 29 when he killed himself.
This young Australian joins the six Australians each day who suicide and leave behind loved ones who will forever ask the question, why?

The report highlights some factors which may trigger suicidal thoughts and behaviour: the loss of a family member or a close friend; divorce in the family or a major family upheaval; the break‐up of a relationship; excessive use of drugs or alcohol; confusion over sexuality or rejection because of sexuality; and school friends who have suicided—or perhaps it is just pressure that seems, to the person, unbearable. Australia, like the rest of the world, has become a more complex place in which to live. There are enormous pressures and difficulties in life today.

For too many Australians, particularly youth, the constant pressure is often unbearable. We have become a community in which we ignore the essential element of what a community is, and that is people. We all seem to find comfort in the excuse that there are a mountain of things that we need to tend and react to. We are becoming a people who just race through each day. Reflection seems to come about when it is just too late.
I was interested in reading an article recently—and I think it was in the Australian—by Dr Peter West, where he analysed some of these aspects. He wrote:

It is tragic that suicide is something Australian males seem to be hugely successful at. Maybe high rates of teenage suicide amongst males suggest that we need to let boys express their feelings. The Australian media seems to be telling us that the pinnacle of achievement for a man is success in sport. Too often, the only patterns boys see modelled by males of television and in homes are anger and drunken revelry.

Why do Greece, Italy and Spain have the lowest rates of male suicide in the developed world? These countries allow men a wider range of emotions than we do in Australia. Their men are more physical. They hug and kiss, and aren't afraid to put their arms around each other. They are not societies in which a man can easily be gay. But surely we can learn from the way their men are valued?

I sincerely do not want to make any political capital about what I am about to say, as I believe this discussion is much too important. I think it has been a very worthwhile discussion—what I have heard of it in this second chamber—but I have never seen an Australia so confused and insecure. What does it say about the values of our community that we insist on focusing on the bottom line, of doing more with much less, of this mantra of downsizing, restructuring, corporatisation and privatisation? What does it say about the values of our community when our young people leave their schools, TAFE and university and cannot find any work?

Indeed, what does it say about the values of our community when there are people in their 20s, 30s and 40s who wake up each morning to go to work, only to come back in the late afternoon with no work to go to the next day? What does it say about the values of our community when a large proportion of the population does not know the name of their next‐door neighbour?

Australians have available to themselves a much wider range of social choices than once before, but this freedom over the range of choices available has been associated with much greater isolation and loneliness for far too many. These are the issues that we as a parliament, and we as a community, need to address. I must say that our suicide figures tell us that we indeed have a long way to go.

Like so many of my colleagues here, I find suicide a tragedy. But let me make a point. I am opposed to suicide and, indeed, I am opposed to capital punishment—I have always been opposed to this. I spoke in this very chamber, and in the House, and voted in favour of the Northern Territory euthanasia legislation some months back. I see no contradiction in this, although it was put to me that there was a contradiction. Euthanasia should not be confused with suicide. They are vastly different, and I suggest the motives leading to the decisions are totally different.

I do think that this seminar on aspects of youth suicide has been very important. Perhaps other committees of the parliament should do much more of this work. Again, I congratulate all those associated with the seminar. I thought it was a very important seminar, and as other people have said, at a very important time, a very topical time.
For the future of Australia and the future of Australia's youth, this report is groundbreaking and an important step. I commend it to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron, Ross, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs present on the day of the seminar, I concur with the concluding remarks of the member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) that it was certainly an excellent exercise. I congratulate the then chair of the committee, the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) and also the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), who underscored the importance of this issue by being present and, in fact, opening the day's proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleagues have ably canvassed the extent of the problem we face and the nature of the trends in Australia, and I think no‐one has risen to their feet without expressing a deep sense of concern at the tragedy which youth suicide represents for the country. Much of the discussion has focused on the alleged causes of youth suicide, on those external pressures which face young people today and which have been particularly identified as being present in many instances of youth suicide. Those pressures have included things like family trauma, divorce, grief over the death of a family member or close friend, personal isolation, unemployment, excessive use of drugs or alcohol, and the phenomenon known as contagion, whereby the example of somebody else's suicide—a person close to someone, or a role model—may influence their decision.

I was particularly influenced and impressed by the testimony of Professor Pierre Baume, who is certainly one of the nation's leading experts on the subject. He talked about the role of depression. He said that it was not depression in isolation, but depression in combination with some of these other factors, that was usually present in the case of those who actually took their own lives or attempted suicide.

I do not speak with any glibness about the subject, as a person who certainly, for periods during my teenage years and early 20s, experienced pretty serious bouts of depression. I know that Winston Churchill, throughout his life, talked about having as companion the black dog of depression. I feel a deep sense of empathy and I share with other members this real sense of concern.

I want to talk primarily, however, about the nature of our response to these problems and, in particular, the nature of the individual response to the external pressures of life. Throughout our history, human beings have been subject to pressures of various kinds—sometimes extraordinary pressures created either by natural disasters or more often, I think, by man's inhumanity to man. The extraordinary thing about our history has been not our inability to respond to those pressures so much as the extraordinary heroism, endurance, determination and capacity to find hope in the face of adverse circumstances.

I want to concentrate on the question not so much of why people take their own lives as of how it is that human beings manage to survive and, indeed, to thrive, very often in conditions of great adversity. A curious aspect of the present challenge is that in material terms our community has never been wealthier than it is at present. That is not to say that there are not pockets of serious poverty and disadvantage but, by comparison with previous generations, the reality is that Australians enjoy a higher standard of life today than they ever have in their history. Even the poorest in our community are, in comparative terms—while still unacceptably poor—better off than their counterparts a generation ago.

So why is it that we now face this increasing propensity of young people to respond to the challenges they face by terminating their lives? One of the factors that Associate Professor Pierre Baume referred to was contagion: the idea that the example of someone else committing suicide may impact on a person's decision about their own life. I rise today with a real sense of gravity, a kind of reluctance, because of a concern that our deliberations here may have the potential not to ameliorate the problem but actually to make it worse.

I recall the story of a community in the United States, in which there had been an outbreak of arson in a number of local schools. The mayor called upon the chief of the fire brigade to go and visit each of the schools and give a lecture to the students on the evils of arson, the result of which was a massive further outbreak in arson around the schools. The lecture had, in effect, promoted to the front of the minds of many of the young people, who had never before contemplated it, the attractions of that particular behaviour.

The member for Throsby mentioned the question of euthanasia. I do not want to reopen that here, but my objection to that legislation was largely based on a concern that, if through legislation we legitimise the taking of a person's life in response to the external circumstances, no matter how grave they may be, there is real potential for that to become an accepted choice for, for example, the young people in our community who may be facing challenges of their own.

We have to recognise the seriousness of those external challenges such as unemployment, such as divorce, such as family trauma, such as the death of a friend. It is the stock in trade of government; it is our first responsibility to take steps to ameliorate the impact of those factors on the community as a whole. Ultimately, our performance in that regard is the matter upon which the community will judge us, and rightly so.

BREAK.PARA: But I would urge this parliament and the government, at the same time, to recognise the appropriate limits of the reach and influence of government. In particular, I have a concern to avoid breaking the link between the individual and the question of responsibility for one's own decisions and actions.

While some may regard me as heartless or lacking in compassion for emphasising this issue, I would vigorously defend that charge on the basis that the only humanitarian response to this problem is an upholding of the principle of human capacity and of human responsibility. One of the most famous students of this ability of human beings to rise above external challenges—to rise above adversity—is the Nobel laureate Primo Levi, and his famous work Moments of Reprieve which studied the responses of those in Auschwitz during the period of the Second World War. Levi was one of about 650 in a group of Italian Jews who were locked in sealed trains and sent to Auschwitz. Only 20 of the group survived and his life's literary study was really the question of why—why did the 20 survive?

Other psychologists have studied responses of those in concentration and prisoner of war camps during the Second World War in Changi and other places, and Levi's conclusions were consistent with the other studies, which suggest, for example, that a person's youth or physical fitness was not a likely indicator of their survival in the face of these enormous hardships. In fact, youth was a disadvantage. They found that things such as the presence in a person of a sense of hope about the future, a sense of mission in their life beyond their immediate circumstances, a sense of goals that were yet to be achieved that were important to them—these things were, in fact, the counterweight in a person's life which gave them this capacity to rise above the horror that they were presently experiencing and gave them the capacity to survive.

I guess that is my principal concern, that it is not within our power in this chamber to so govern the fortunes and vicissitudes of life as to give anyone in this country an assurance that they will not, at some time, be faced with adversity. It is not within our power to be able to guarantee that any person's life experience will be fair or just.

If you will indulge me for a moment, Mr Deputy Speaker, I recall so vividly, because of the repetition of it in my experience as a child, going to my father and complaining that some decision or another was unfair—for example, in the distribution of resources among my five brothers and sisters and I. My father's inevitable response was `Never pretend that the world is fair.' Some may say that was a harsh and uncaring response. In retrospect, it was an important and valuable response to me in that what he said was, `Your success in life will not be determined by the nature of the challenges and obstacles you face, but by the nature of your response to them.' And this is, I think, the critical question that we have to address.

While we have to look at how we ameliorate these external factors which cause insecurity, alienation, loneliness and depression, we have also got to look at how we strengthen the inner resolve of young Australians, at how we can encourage and instil that sense of mission, that sense of purpose, that sense of ambition, that sense of hope for the future, which provides a counterweight, a kind of ballast to resist the inevitable vicissitudes, the slings and arrows of outrageous fortune.

In that regard, we have got to be very careful to resist attributing blame for youth suicide on something such as government policy. While I have appreciated a very high level of bipartisanship in this debate, there have been, for example, inferences that the culpability of the government in failing to provide jobs for young people is directly causal in this question of youth suicide. Similarly, others have argued that the escalation of youth suicide can be attributed to alleged defects in regional development policy.

Frankly, I regard that line of argument as being probably the most dangerous, the most insidious, the most reprehensible of anything that I have heard, in this chamber or the other, since being elected to parliament, because we seriously run the risk of clothing the suicidal instinct with legitimacy from the highest quarter of representative authority in the land. By characterising a young person as a victim of these external pressures we risk glamorising and legitimising that most tragic of all responses—to take one's own life.

I concur with previous speakers who have urged us to direct our resources and attention to what is a most grave, pressing and tragic fact of contemporary Australian life. But, in doing so, I also urge us to uphold the basic principle of personal and individual responsibility because, ultimately, it is not unemployment which kills a person, it is not depression which kills a person, it is not even isolation which kills a person. It is a gun, it is a hose pipe attached to an exhaust, it is a large number of barbiturates.

What we have to do is strengthen the resolve of the individual in that moment, strengthen their sense of hope. It is not something that governments, in isolation, can do. In fact, it is something which we have to recruit the whole community to do. And that kind of constructive, hope oriented response is the one which I think will be most helpful. I want to conclude by saying that the development of character comes not through the absence of challenges but by resistance to them. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lawrence, Carmen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to speak briefly on the report on aspects of youth suicide by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs, not least so that I can indicate the extent to which the current report builds on work that has been done, and I hope will continue to be done, in this very important area. I am sure in this debate we have heard a recitation of a large number of facts about youth suicide, but I think some of them bear re‐emphasising because they do tell us something about the contemporary nature of the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a fact that youth suicide in Australia is amongst the highest in the industrialised world. That is why we have to look at it with uniquely Australian solutions. The World Health Organisation statistics from 1993, which allow some comparisons internationally, show that Australia recorded the fourth highest rate in a list of 14 countries for suicide deaths amongst young males aged 15 to 24. So we have a very unenviable record in this area.

It is a fact too that in that same year—and it is hard to get more contemporary figures—suicide was the recorded cause of death of more than 2,000 Australians. So it is a significant problem for the community. Sadly, 80 per cent of those were males, with 20 per cent of them aged between 15 and 24, so that is where the epidemic rests. Data show that while the rate of completed suicide is higher for males than females, the rate of attempts is about the same, suggesting that males generally use what might be regarded as more deadly methods. It is also a fact that there may be as many as 30 or 40 suicide attempts for every one that is completed among young people in Australia, so the rate could very well be higher.

It is also a fact that young males living in rural and remote areas have consistently higher rates of suicide than those in the city. That has been true for some time, and it does appear to be getting worse. Guns are the main method of suicide in these cases. One can hope that gun control legislation may well have a positive effect on the rate of suicide in country areas.

BREAK.PARA: It is also a fact that male deaths by suicide in the 15‐24 age group have increased by almost 50 per cent over 15 years from 1979 to 1993. That is where I disagree a little with the previous speaker. I think when you see those trends, you have to ask why and that inevitably means you have to look at the wider society as well as the individual characteristics. Why are people making those decisions? What pressures are on them, both at the level of the individual and the broader group to which they belong? We can identify male, country, young as being the critical variables. Add to that, of course, the high rate of suicide amongst our indigenous people and you have got another group who clearly require special attention if we are to understand ways and means of reducing the impact on individuals and families in the wider community.

If you want to look at it in, I suppose, what might be in this context regarded as crude economic terms, in the period 1983 to 1992, an estimated 230,000 years of potential life of 15‐ to 24‐year olds were lost due to suicide. I am sure we are all well aware, especially those people who have been on the committee, that research has shown that up to 90 per cent of young people who suicide have some evidence of psychiatric illness before their death. Depression is the most common of those illnesses. Risk factors for youth suicide not only include mental illness, but also alcohol and drug abuse, a history of physical and sexual abuse within their families, family breakdown generally, homelessness, unemployment and incarceration. Many of these are symptoms of the same set of problems, I think.

These risk factors, as I say, occur in greater proportion in some sections of our community. That is why we need to address these broader, as well as individual, matters. I was pleased, when I was minister, that really for the first time in a serious way, the Commonwealth government got involved with youth suicide. It has always been regarded as a matter for the state governments and had been left on their plate, so to speak. But there was clearly a lack of national focus and coordination, something that the committee has recognised, and the Commonwealth government, I think, does have a particular role to play here, not in the delivery of services but rather in ensuring that the best research is done, that there is coordination and that best practice is promoted. Because of that I launched `Here for life; a national plan for youth in distress', which was really only just beginning when we left government, together with Youth suicide in Australia: a background monograph, which gave a lot of the detail that is now being used by this committee and people working in the field.

I think it is fair to say that the Commonwealth had been concerned for some time about the mental health and wellbeing of Australia's young people, particularly those in those most disadvantaged areas, and there had been a number of initiatives developed by my predecessors to address this area of concern. For instance, in 1991, the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs funded a report Youth suicide in Australia; prevention and strategies. They were clearly concerned about the link between unemployment, particularly long‐term unemployment, and the possible effects on youth suicide. As a result, in 1993, there were a series of innovative projects to support the unemployed and at-risk young people as an attempt to prevent that as an outcome.

In 1993 the Department of Human Services and Health, as it was then, commenced three years of funding for youth suicide prevention initiatives, particularly in rural areas since that is one of the key focuses necessary in any program, including training for youth, health and education sector staff and support for the prevention of copycat suicides that we heard about earlier.

I think it is important to recognise in this area that we really do not know what works. These trial projects, these innovative programs, are actually critical to getting it right in the long term in terms of policy intervention. It needs to happen at every level from individual counselling to identification of risk factors, and attempting to address those, to a broader social discussion about suicide and its effects. The Commonwealth when I was minister went further and worked with state and territory health ministers on a number of additional initiatives, including the national mental health strategy which I think is still shaping what the states are doing in this area, and we tried to develop a number of innovative service models.

There was also a health services for homeless youth program that piloted initiatives to provide mental health support to young people who were homeless and at risk. I think that deserves to be supported in the long term. The state and territory health ministers endorsed a joint program or a joint approach called, `The health of young Australians; a national health policy for children and young people'. I mention these because I think it is absolutely critical that, with a change of government or a change of minister, these initiatives are not dropped simply because they belonged to the other team.

As has already been indicated, it is critical that we continue to build in this very difficult area and not try to score political points about it. I think we can be quite sharp in our analysis of what it is that appears to be contributing to these growing rates. I think invariably it would be a matter that fell across the responsibility of all political parties and at all levels of government. You would not be able to find a single government who could claim to occupy a high moral ground in this area. Equally, you could not claim that any one type of government was responsible for the problem. Nonetheless, I think it should be a focus for our monitoring of the success, or otherwise, of programs that are being introduced, or failing to be introduced, by governments.

At the same time, all the Australian health ministers agreed with the document `Better health outcomes for Australia' that we should aim to reduce suicide rates of people with mental illness by 15 per cent over the next 10 years. A specific target was set at that time and all ministers signed up to it.

When we went the next step and tried to develop a national plan for youth in distress, as a result of the research that had been done, we also included significant additional funding. It was well short of what is actually needed to address the problem but, nonetheless, the first time the Commonwealth had really put serious money into this area on a coordinated basis. I welcome the fact that the current government has not only continued to do that, but has actually expanded the funding that is available.

What we were trying to do—and I know that a lot going on now is building on this work, and I am pleased to see that—was to provide a response that was coordinated for young people. The two major aims of the strategy were to build on the existing initiatives that were taking place in some states and to develop new and innovative practices, which would better meet the needs of young people, particularly in crisis and risk, and to integrate these new models into ongoing practice reforms in health, welfare and education.

One of the things that I know well from my time working with the health department in psychiatric services, in particular, is that there is a temptation to do your own little things and not look across borders and across disciplines to find good ways of approaching these questions. There is a bit of a temptation to re‐invent the wheel on a continuing basis. Building on best practice is one of the important outcomes not only of the work that we have done but also of the work recommended by the committee.

I must say I was a little surprised that one of the recommendations was the establishment of a new national group to advise the minister and the department of human services and health, because one was established with some very fine people on it. I understand it is continuing. I am not quite sure how it will relate to the recommended body, the National Advisory Council on Youth Suicide Prevention, that the committee has put before the parliament. I await with interest exactly how that might be done because some people of considerable expertise are on that committee. That really does represent, quite apart from any political spin, the best in the country. I would hope that their expertise is not lost or in some way muddled by having two bodies. I certainly will leave that to the committee and the minister.

I think it is very important too that, in disseminating these approaches, we are quite bold publicly. It is important that we do not develop a concern that causes us not to speak about suicide. I share some of the concerns of the previous speaker that we certainly do not want to endorse the idea that, if you are at risk in some of the ways that I have described, it is legitimate for you to see suicide as an outcome. But we have to recognise that people undertake these behaviours under conditions typically of considerable long‐term stress and so it is important for us, as a community, to be able to talk about it.

It is important to identify those things in our community at the broadest level which may be leading to those big increases that I talked about: the high rate of youth suicide, the high rate of rural suicide, the high rate of male suicide and the high rate of suicide amongst indigenous people. If you look at all those categories, with the exception of maleness, all of them represent areas where you have considerable economic disadvantage. I do not think you can overlook that. It is not a political observation. It has been happening for some time in this country. As the gap between rich and poor, along with the access to resources in our community, has grown wider—and it has, in general terms—we have seen an increase in suicide. You cannot ignore the possibility that at least some of what we have seen of that increase is due precisely to the fact that these young people believe that they have no future.

All of us here would want to argue against that view. Because you are unemployed for a period of time does not condemn you to irrelevance and it certainly does not suggest that suicide is a legitimate way of solving your problems. Look at the other stresses that are faced by these young people along with unemployment, very low income and a perception—remember always—of a society that they are not part of. That is a very real concern here.

They look at a community which is, by and large, wealthy and comfortable. Even though a lot of people are suffering from job insecurity, they look around them and see a level of material wealth and comfort within the family and make invidious comparisons with their own position. That inevitably means that they will experience a sense of despair and desperation. It is not just good enough to support them in their individual distress. We also have to look at the pressures of a wider kind on them that will lead some to break under those circumstances. Many will not.

I was interested to hear that the previous speaker mentioned Primo Levi. He is someone for whom I have had a great deal of admiration over many years. I have read most of his works. I think it is worth noting that, ultimately, he suicided. Despite all of the work that he had done in trying to make clear how the human spirit had triumphed, in the end he succumbed to depression, almost certainly as a result of the appalling experiences he had during the Holocaust. Whatever his reasons, we will never know precisely why he did it. In many of his works he expounded the view that he could not, in a sense, justify his own continuing existence. Why had he survived and others not?

It is that sense of worthlessness that comes through in a lot of the material about young people in distress, whether they eventually commit suicide or whether they end up on our roads or in our prisons doing something very similar. I think we need to look at that `acting out' of the problems of youth too in somewhat the same way.

I remember being approached by a psychiatrist working in this area, but mainly working with juvenile offenders. He said for all the world he could not tell the difference between the profile of a seriously depressed and suicidal young person and a young person who is out on the road stealing cars or breaking and entering or sniffing glue. They basically had the same problems with their own self-esteem, as well as the same social circumstances.

Suicide, in that sense, is a symptom of a broader social problem. Of course, it is a tragedy for the individuals who finally do commit suicide, and for many others. It is something that, as a community, we have to speak about clearly. We have to indicate that we understand it is not just an individual response but that it is in the context of social pressures which governments can and should alleviate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bartlett, Kerry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The death of a loved one is always sad. A premature death, the death of a young person, is particularly painful. But suicide, the self-imposed, premature ending of a young life, is a tragedy which is devastating for those associated with it and it cuts to the very heart of our community.

SPEECH.PARA: The facts are alarming. In 1995, 350 young men and 84 young women took their own lives. In the last 30 years the young male suicide rate has almost trebled, and for young females it has doubled. We have seen a similar trend in most industrialised countries but, alarmingly, Australia's rates are amongst the highest in the world, with just a handful of countries having higher rates. We have seen, sadly, the same alarming trend in countries such as New Zealand, the USA and Canada.

Even more disturbing is the fact that these figures perhaps grossly underestimate the reality and the seriousness of the problem. For every suicide that is completed there are many unsuccessful attempts. In fact, there are an estimated 10 admissions to hospital for attempted suicide for each suicide that actually occurs. Also, perhaps many of our motor vehicle accidents involving young people are disguised suicides.

The causes are many and complex and the forum on youth suicide organised by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs certainly highlighted many of those. The speakers—Dr James Harrison, Professor Kosky, Dr Meg Smith and Associate Professor Pierre Baume—pointed to a number of contributing factors.

It is important that we look at these contributing factors and the causes not in terms of an academic study, not in terms of an attempt to gain knowledge for its own sake, but in terms of an attempt to come to grips with the causes so that we may better address the issues and develop policies which may help us address this alarming problem in our community.

First of all, they pointed to a range of adverse social conditions about which a number of my colleagues have spoken here this morning. They are factors that seem to be common in those countries that have high youth suicide rates. Those factors include increased and high levels of divorce; high levels of unemployment, especially for males; high levels of unemployment for males when there were high employment levels for young females; declining rates of church membership; and other social changes that seem to be common in those countries where youth suicide rates are high and increasing.

They pointed to a number of personal characteristics and situations that contributed alarmingly to the problem, and we have heard much of these this morning, including symptoms of depression and, often, mental illness. Studies show that up to two‐thirds of the young people who had taken their own lives had had a history of depression and, often, a history that fringed on mental illness as well. Suicide can be related to increased levels of stress for young people: levels of stress arising out of conflict with parents; levels of stress arising out of school work and problems at school; levels of stress related to romantic problems, the breakdown of relationships; and levels of stress related to a significant social upheaval in their lives.

Another factor that was very prominent in the thinking of some of those speakers at the forum was the very high level of alcohol consumption, which seemed to have a high correlation with rates of suicide. Other factors include the weakening of networks of interpersonal support—no‐one to turn to when things get tough; interference with help‐seeking behaviour and delivery of services; a change in the sense of community, with less family support, a lesser role for churches and other organisations that in the past have offered support that is so much needed when a crisis comes; and degrees of marginalisation, particularly for Aborigines and homosexuals, especially in rural and remote areas where the support networks are not available.

The speakers also pointed to family problems, to families where there was a strong background of violence or abuse, which was noted in up to 50 per cent of cases of attempted suicide. A history of family discord and low cohesiveness was found by a Queensland study to be a major factor in 70 per cent of suicide cases for young people. Other problems pointed to were the death of a close relative, the separation or divorce of parents and family breakdown. Interestingly, suicide rates were lowest among those who were married and were highest for those who were divorced or separated and for young people who were from families which had experienced divorce or separation.

The issues of contagion and imitation have been raised here this morning as well. Just a few weeks ago, for instance, in one of our newspapers, we read of the tragic case of five drinking mates from the Southern Highlands township of Bundanoon who, within a period of a couple of weeks, had taken their lives, one after the other. There seems to be evidence that when friends, mates and peers have succumbed to the pressure to take their own lives, this impacts on those who are left behind.

Many of the speakers, and particularly Professor Pierre Baume, made much of the impact of the media, of the focus of the media, of telefiction, of heavy metal subcultures, of the role of the Internet in suicide in young people and the impact that that has on framing their thinking. An article in the Daily Telegraph just last week, in fact, spoke of two 15‐year‐old girls who jumped off a bridge. It says:

After using a felt pen to write of their love for two boys and their devotion to grunge bands Nirvana and silverchair on a wall, two teenage girls held hands and jumped off a footbridge on to a freeway.
One died the other one survived.The article goes on:
Nirvana lead singer Kurt Cobain killed himself with a shotgun in April 1994 after openly talking about suicide.
Newcastle band silverchair has a song, Suicidal dream, featuring the line, "I fantasise about my death, I kill myself from holding my breath."
This sort of portrayal by our supposed entertainers, and by some in the media, certainly has done much to distort the thinking of many of our susceptible young people.

In summary, from that forum, we saw that increased pressure, depression, reduced self‐esteem, decreased ability to cope, and a decreased cause for hope all contributed to the tragic and alarming increase in levels of youth suicide in this country. There is an enormous challenge for us as a government. There is an enormous challenge for us as a community and there is an enormous challenge for us as individuals.

Firstly, for the government, there is a challenge to put into place policies that reduce some of those background pressures, some of those social factors that may in fact lead young people to think that life is not worth living. We are all aware of the need to tackle the issues of youth unemployment, and both the former government and the current government see that, quite rightly, as a very high priority. We are all aware of the need for government to provide policies of support for families so that the family unit is strengthened and not endangered.

In addition to these policies that will change the structure of society and perhaps reduce some of those pressures, there needs to be a much greater emphasis on direct policies of assistance, direct policies to tackle the issue of youth suicide. We saw with the previous government the $13 million budget for the `Here for life' youth suicide prevention initiative—a very worthwhile initiative. We have seen with the current government a budget of $19 million funding for the national youth suicide prevention strategy. There needs to be much greater attention to these sorts of programs which will help organisations who are working at the coalface with our susceptible young people—organisations such as Lifeline, Kids Helpline and Youth Insearch.

We need services which are accessible, credible, relevant and attractive to young people. We need services which are non‐judgmental, confidential and free. We need services which are flexible and innovative in their approaches to the needs of service users. We need services which are best practice in the treatment of young people who are depressed or in crisis. We need greater attention to training for educationalists and medical practitioners, who are often the first point of contact for those suffering depression or contemplating suicide. We need greater attention to recognition of early warning signs and to counselling for those under threat.

The forum made many recommendations to the government: that a national advisory council be established; that a research advisory committee also be set up; and that immediate attention be given both to educating young people in treating depression and to standardising procedures for hospitals when treating young people presenting with self‐inflicted harm or attempted suicide. We cannot rely only on the government, though. I believe that ultimately the issue of youth suicide cannot be resolved totally by the government. The former speaker, the member for Parramatta (Mr Ross Cameron) made reference to this.

The government can really only tinker around the edges, because the incidence of youth suicide is reflective of problems at the very heart of our society and ultimately requires solutions that also go to the heart of our society. It involves restoring those values, ideals, relationships, structures and behaviour patterns which enhance life, raise self‐esteem and offer hope for our young people. We all have a responsibility here.

There is a role for the media. The media has a responsibility to refrain from pushing ideas and lifestyles that are destructive of moral values, that are destructive of families and that diminish the value of life. The media has a responsibility to avoid excessive and often voyeuristic portrayals of incidents of suicide that may lead others to copy them. The media has a responsibility in avoiding airplay of songs which promote or romanticise the idea of suicide. Instead of its hand‐wringing exercise of sensational journalism and finger‐pointing, it has a responsibility to share in promoting positive values.

There is a responsibility for parents to give greater focus to the needs of their children, focusing on the children's needs rather than their own. There is a great responsibility for parents to work at keeping their relationships together. It is perhaps not coincidental that Australia, as well as having one of the highest suicide rates in the world, has one of the highest divorce rates in the world. I am not saying that that is always avoidable: clearly, it is not; but often it is seen as an easy option and an easy way out, regardless of the impact that that has on our children and our young people. We have a responsibility to raise our children in a way which encourages them to look beyond themselves and their own problems, and to consider the problems of others and their relationships of others. We need to raise our children in a way which considers service rather than a desire to be served.

I believe that in the community there is a place for a much greater focus on spiritual values, on issues of meaning and purpose in life. We have taken for granted too much the destructive philosophies of secular humanism, hedonism, existentialism, reductionism and nihilism. It is about time that we started to realise that there is meaning, hope and significance in life and that, unless we address these core spiritual values, ultimately there will always be a degree of frustration—for our young people as well as for us—in searching for meaning and purpose in life.

I believe as well that there is a need for society to emphasise again the sanctity of human life, particularly in the face of the assault by a flirtation with euthanasia and a blind acceptance of abortion on demand. If we give on one hand to our young people a very strong message that death is a solution to problems such as pain, that death is a solution to unwanted pregnancies, we can hardly be surprised if this does not have some impact on the way life is regarded and on the way suicide is in fact regarded when things get tough. We cannot keep, as a society, sending mixed messages to our young people.

The high and rising levels of youth suicide are a reflection of many underlying maladies in society. There is clearly no easy solution, but they should be sending the alarm bells ringing that all is not well and that the fundamental reordering of values and priorities is needed. These warning signs need to be heeded not only by governments but by all in our community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price, Roger, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose I am a reluctant contributor in this debate. In fact, I can say that I kept my name off the speakers list for some time and have only just recently decided to place it on. I can tell you the reason for this, and that is that, out in my part of the world, we have a very high youth suicide rate. In fact, there is one particular church that I am able to help—I hope not improperly—in preparing the funeral service notice for the funerals that are held there, and particularly the suicides. It is in this way that I get to know and see some of the tragic results of youth suicide and the impact it has on families and the community.

SPEECH.PARA: Generally speaking, I always say about problems—I think lots of others approach it the same way—that we need to break them down into their smallest parts and concentrate on those parts, particularly those within our grasp. I think the first thing that you have to really grasp about youth suicide is that it is a complex problem. If we could merely say that suicides are a result of depression, then it would be relatively easy. We could then go out perhaps and try to identify those that are depressed and high risk and develop some strategies. But suicide is complex.

When you combat some problems in my electorate, you find that there are other problems as well. For example, I can well recall—I am very grateful to the former Minister for Social Security, the member for Sydney (Mr Baldwin), coming out with his officials, and representatives of some other departments—where, on the ground, we were looking at what was needed to get young people trained up and back into work. We calculated that there were nine different Commonwealth and state departments that we actually needed to coordinate to be able to provide a solution.

One of the great weaknesses of our form of administration is that we compartmentalise things within portfolios. Let me give you another example. On the issue of literacy, an important issue in my electorate, we have the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp) in the House constantly speaking about the issue of illiteracy, saying that it is important. I suspect he is a little short on solutions, but certainly he is lifting up community awareness about literacy. We should have our attention raised, I guess.

However, you cannot teach people to read if they have a juvenile justice problem. You cannot teach people to read and be numerate if they are hungry. You cannot teach people to read if they are homeless. You cannot teach people to read if they have other social problems and dysfunctional families. In the quest to solve a literacy problem, you have got to deal with each and every other issue. We are not equipped to do that. Not only is there the break between Commonwealth, state and local government, but how do you coordinate them all?

I think this is where, when we are discussing youth suicide, we have to understand that we need to bring a holistic approach to the problem. Let me run through some statistics. In 1995, there were 350 male suicides and 84 young female suicides. The male suicides represent 25 per cent of the male deaths; the young female suicides represent 17 per cent of young female deaths. The first thing I would say is that we need to get better statistics, and we have to listen to young people in particular.

Why better statistics? When is a drug overdose really a drug overdose and not a suicide? It is very clear, I guess, if they leave a note behind. When is a car accident merely a function of perhaps too much alcohol or careless or negligent driving, or a suicide? The point I am trying to make here is that I certainly suspect, and others in a better position than I in my electorate suspect, that these statistics are grossly under‐representative. We may have a much bigger problem than we credit. I was interested to try and get a grab on local suicide figures, and I cannot do that. But what I can say is that, in one parish, among under‐25s in the years 1987 to 1996, we have had 291 deaths. A significant proportion of those are suicides.

I should also put it on record that, although death confronts us all, I think that one of the most difficult things for parents and societies to deal with is the death of young people. I do not believe it ever leaves the parents unscarred. But in our society there is, I guess, no greater feeling of emptiness and frustration than results from young people having got to a point where they have elected to take their own lives. That presents an additional degree of difficulty.

I commend the Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs for holding its seminar. The good thing is that it has held a seminar in the parliament and invited a whole variety of people with a range of experience to meet to discuss the problem. I was pleased, as I said, that one of the community groups from my electorate participated. But I say to the chairman of the committee that, if all we do in this parliament concerning youth suicide is merely to have this seminar, we will be poorly serving both the young people and the parents.

I certainly think that we need to start having the idea that youth are worth investing in—if we want to talk in economic terms—and that a life, if we can prevent it from being taken so young, has a whole contribution to make to our local community, to our society, to our nation. We do need more statistics; we are a statistical society and it allows us to focus on and see the dimensions of the problems.

I believe that some of the solutions are out there already and we need to be working on them. Firstly, the measure of any society is the value the society places on the worth of the individual and the idea that the loss of one individual is a loss too great to bear. I always tend to rattle on about education but, in the area of schools, it is really important to pick up on the problems as early as possible—for instance, literacy problems. I really find it difficult when people wish to politicise this, when we know very well that the money we invest as a nation in early education—that is, in infants in years 1 and 2—is money well spent. It gets them on the reading trail. It is so much cheaper to remedy problems in years 1 and 2 than later in primary school or in junior high school.

I have said before in this place that I regret that some of my high schools graduate students in year 10 who are illiterate. They are fully certified as having successfully completed the course, but they are illiterate. It does not mean that they are dumb people; it does not mean that they are less intelligent. But it does mean that they have not had the benefit of all the excitement that comes with being able to read and write. Early intervention requires extra teachers and extra people. It is money well spent; it is a terrific investment.

During the debates on work for the dole, it really upset me to listen to some of the government backbenchers who were suggesting that this single measure was somehow going to favourably impact on youth suicide. I do not think it is. I do not, for one minute, believe that it will. Youth suicide is far too complex. The idea that people should be able to finish their schooling and be gainfully employed is very important. As a society, we are going to have to decide whether we are going to test people as to whether they are employed gainfully, being paid wages and whether they are working in either public or private enterprise. What about those people who can never get a job? There are just not jobs there; the economy is not powering away. We do have a double standard. We are labelling these people in an era of high youth unemployment as failures. I do not think they are failures. I suspect that we are failing them as a society.

I wanted to speak about the contribution of the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) and his comments about the Child Support Agency and divorce. I got into a lot of hot water when I suggested that people—not necessarily youth—were suiciding as a result of their predicament in regard to child support. I was accused of undermining the scheme. I always stand up and report the facts as I know them. Regrettably people do suicide and we need to reform not only the Child Support Agency but also family law—they are linked.

I think children have generally the entitlement to access to both parents; and if they do, they immeasurably benefit from it. It would be nice if people did not divorce, but that is not the reality. The idea that the honourable member for McPherson has is that if we have all mothers staying at home to rear a family, this will solve all our social problems. I never deprecate a family where a mother or a parent has elected to take on, full time, that child‐rearing role. But to go from that to saying that all families should be in this situation is grossly unfair. It pays no heed to the revolution that has occurred for women's role in our society.

Why shouldn't women be able to aspire to having a relationship, having children, but also having a career? They are no lesser mothers because they aspire to and fulfil those roles, but I think there are too many men in our society who are really captured in old‐world views and old‐world thinking, and have not updated themselves to it. As I say, I do not criticise those families where there is a parent at home, full time, raising children. But do not expect that all families will want to make the same choice or, indeed, will have any choice about that. The more we start spending money on live families and relationships, instead of on dead families where the marriage or the relationship has broken down, the better off we will be. We spend $250 million in family law on dead marriages and peanuts on live ones. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Mr Lloyd) adjourned.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Main Committee adjourned at 1.07 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Taxation Returns: Prostitutes and Drug Dealers

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cameron, Eoin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a media conference on 4 June 1997 in which the shadow Treasurer asked how many hookers or drug pedlars were going to fill out their 15% value added tax forms.

(2) How many tax returns were filed between 1990‐91 and 1996‐97 where the person's occupation was listed as (a) prostitute or a derivation of prostitute or (b) drug pedlar or a derivation of drug pedlar.

(3) Can hookers or drug pedlars, as well as other occupations, evade taxation under the present tax system by accepting cash payments and not declaring them; if so, did this occur under the former Government; if so, what was the estimated sum of tax evaded in the last three years of the former Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable members question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There is no value added tax in Australia.

(2) No information is available for sources of income from illicit "drug peddling" as this industry is not included in the statistics gathered by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) from the industrial classification system.

The ATO does have a classification for escort agencies and massage parlour operators. Generally speaking, where a taxation return is filed in a particular year, it is in respect of income earned in the previous financial year.
The number of returns lodged for escort agencies by financial year is as follows:
Statistics for the income year 1995‐96 will not be available until October 1997.

(3) It may be possible under the present system for people in certain occupations to evade paying tax by accepting cash payments and not declaring them. Consequently, it is also possible that this could have occurred under the former Government.

However, it has long been recognised that persons engaged in illegal and criminal business activities represent the least compliant of all taxpayers whether dealing in cash or otherwise. In recognition of this the Commissioner maintains a Program specifically tasked to collect revenue arising from industries such as prostitution and illegal drug cultivation, importation, manufacture and distribution.
This Program forms part of the current focus on activities in the cash economy following on the Report of the Cash Economy Task Force established by the Commissioner in November 1996.

It is clear that major organised crime, particularly international drug trafficking, is inextricably linked to schemes and arrangements to launder large amounts of cash for tax evasion purposes. As a result, the ATO is currently working closely with the National Crime Authority conducting investigations specifically funded in the last Budget.
It is not possible to accurately estimate the amount of tax evaded in the prostitution and illicit drug industries.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 25 August, 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do the terms of the Australian Tax Office's 1996 Form C (Appendix 1) oblige strata title bodies corporate to lodge an income tax return in respect of bank interest earned by the body corporate even where that body corporate has no other source of income; if so, is it a fact that (a) most strata title bodies corporate earn minimal income through bank interest and (b) in many cases the costs of engaging a professional to prepare the taxation return will often exceed the amount of tax payable.
(2) Will he introduce a threshold below which strata title bodies corporate are not required to lodge a taxation return.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Appendix 1 of the 1996 Form C Instructions reflects the income tax law that treats strata title bodies corporate as public companies and, as such, tax is assessed on the taxable income with no minimum threshold.

(1) (a) Although figures about the amount of bank interest income earned by strata title bodies corporate are not available, the following chart of the level of tax payable by strata bodies corporate in the 1995/96 income year is provided:

ROW.ENTRY: Percentage of Bodies Corporate returns lodged

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (b) Accurate data as to the cost of engaging a professional to prepare a taxation return for a strata title body corporate is not available, however the taxation returns for this type of taxpayer are generally simple and would not be expected to command high fees. It is noted, also, that the cost of having a recognised professional tax adviser prepare a taxation return is an allowable deduction in the year the cost is incurred.

(2) A tax‐free threshold is an integral part of the progressive income tax system for personal taxpayers. It serves the objective of vertical equity by ensuring that personal taxpayers who earn low incomes pay little or no income tax, whereas taxpayers on larger incomes pay progressively higher marginal rates of tax.

The corporate tax system is inherently different from the personal tax system as there is a single tax rate of 36 percent and no tax‐free threshold. There is, therefore, no reason to treat income earned by a strata title body corporate any differently (by providing a tax free threshold) to income earned by any other business entity. Moreover, introducing a tax‐free threshold for bodies corporate would provide tax advantages to their members, irrespective of their income levels, and would lead to pressure for a similar tax‐free threshold from other industries and sectors.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Fresh Orange Juice: Wholesale Sales Tax

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones, Barry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 25 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is fresh orange juice to be regarded as a food with respect to considerations before the National Food Authority: if not, why not.
(2) What level of wholesale sales tax applies to (a) fresh orange juice and (b) orange juice reconstituted from concentrate.
(3) If either of the rates referred to in part (2) is not zero, why not.
(4) What level of wholesale sales tax applies to (a) milk, (b) flavouring essences, (c) bread, (d) Vegemite, (e) butter and (f) cheese.
(5) If there are differences in the rates applying to each of the products referred to in part (4), why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer to part (1) of the honourable member's question:
(1) Yes. Orange juice is currently defined within Standard 07—Orange Juice and Related Products—of the Food Standards Code.

(2) Fruit juices, including orange juice are subject to sales tax at the concessional rate of 12 percent provided the beverage contains at least 25 percent by volume of juices of fruits. The concessional rate applies to both fresh and reconstituted fruit juice.

(3) Under the sales tax law most food for human consumption is exempt from tax. However, most beverages are excluded from this exemption and are either taxable (for example soft drinks) at the general rate of 22% or specifically made exempt (for example milk). Fruit juices and flavoured milk are taxed at the lower concessional rate of 12%.

(4) Plain milk is exempt from sales tax under its own specific exemption item. Bread, Vegemite, butter and cheese are exempt from sales tax as food for human consumption. Flavouring essences used in the preparation of foodstuffs are also exempt from sales tax. Flavouring essences used in the preparation of beverages are taxable at the general rate of 22 percent unless they contain at least 25 percent by volume of fruit juice, in which case they are taxed at the concessional rate of 12 percent.
(5) Under the sales tax law most food for human consumption is exempt from tax but most beverages are taxable.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Martin, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 26 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) conducting a review of income of Australia's Olympic athletes; if so, what is the purpose of the review.
(2) Has the ATO established an Olympic Project to target the income of Olympians.

(3) Will all sources of income, including income provided by the Australian Olympic Committee and the Australian Sports Commission, be the subject of the review and subject to the changed taxation arrangements.
(4) Will the review penalise potential Olympic athletes by causing them undue hardship through the taxation system.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) is conducting a review of the income derived by all sports people. The ATO is conducting the review for the purposes of preparing a public ruling, which will cover income derived through sporting pursuits. It is anticipated that the public ruling will address all aspects of sporting income which is derived by sports people in general.
The Ruling is being drafted to clarify the law in this area, to thereby enable sports people at all levels to comply with their obligations under the taxation laws.

(2) No, the ATO has not established an Olympic project to specifically target the income derived by Olympic athletes. The ATO has, however, established a team which is responsible for dealing with all taxation implications in respect of the Olympic Games.

(3) All sources of income are being examined in the course of preparation of the public ruling. The ATO has met with officials of the Australian Sports Commission (ASC) and the Australian Olympic Committee (AOC) to discuss the public ruling, and to obtain information for the purposes of the Ruling. The ATO will continue to consult with these bodies, and other interested bodies and organisations, throughout the following months.
(4) The ruling will ensure that people who derive income through sporting pursuits will know whether such income should form part of their assessable income.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Ageing in Place Rights: Financial Assistance

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mossfield, Frank, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 23 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Will providers be given financial assistance where residents in a hostel facility exercise their Ageing in Place rights not to be moved to a full nursing home facility despite their category being upgraded, if so what.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Under the new aged care arrangements, the single Resident Classification Scale is used to classify relative care needs, and allocate funding for residents, irrespective of their location in a low level care facility (hostel) or high level care facility (nursing home).

Some providers may choose to provide care across the full range of dependency so as to meet people's care needs as they change. Other providers may choose to continue to specialise in high or low levels of dependency or in dementia care. Any changes in the resident mix will be their choice.
Providers who choose to offer a more extensive range of services must have the necessary staffing and infrastructure in place to enable them to deliver an appropriate standard of care.

The new funding system supports providers in the level of care services they wish to provide by providing a level of funding which changes to reflect the increasing care needs of residents who "age in place".

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mossfield, Frank, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 25 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Is there a lack of co‐operation between State and Federal governments over the introduction of standards for the aged care industry; if so, (a) what steps are being taken to resolve the issue and (b) when will agreement be reached.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

BREAK.PARA: There has been no lack of co‐operation between State and Federal governments in the introduction of the new standards for residential aged care facilities.

The development of standards is a Commonwealth responsibility. The new standards were developed in close partnership between representatives from consumer groups, aged care industry associations, unions and the Government.

The new Residential Care Standards were introduced from 1 October 1997 (Quality of Care Principles 1997, Schedule 3). Aged care facilities will be assessed against these standards until such time as they seek accreditation during a three year transition period from January 1998 to January 2001. Facilities seeking accreditation from January 1998 will be assessed against the Accreditation Standards (Quality of Care Principles 1997, Schedule 2).

Both the Residential Care Standards and Accreditation Standards require service providers to identify and comply with all relevant Commonwealth, State and Territory legislation, regulatory requirements, professional standards and guidelines.

My predecessor, the Hon J. Moylan MP, wrote to State and Territory Health and Community Services Ministers on 24 September 1997 concerning the implications of State and Territory health and related regulations for Commonwealth funded facilities. Mrs Moylan sought agreement to a protocol for the regulation of hostels, to operate for a two year period, to enable a review of existing Commonwealth and State health regulations applying to aged care hostels. The proposed protocol reflects an approach agreed by Commonwealth and State officials to clarify similar issues in relation to building requirements under the Building Code of Australia.

The Australian Building Codes Board, in conjunction with State building authorities, has also commenced a review of the classification of residential aged care buildings. The objective is to ensure that the Code licensing requirements can accommodate the development of integrated aged care facilities.

I am confident that the States and Territories will, as they have done to date on other aspects of the reforms, co‐operate in arriving at a sensible approach that will give certainty to providers and maximise the potential of the aged care reforms to achieve improvements without compromising the quality of care.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Aboriginal Groups: Mining Royalties and Other Payments

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 2 October 1997:

BREAK.PARA: What are the details of royalties and other payments paid to Aboriginal groups each year in respect of mining in the Northern Territory.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The payment of royalties to Aboriginal people in respect of mining on Aboriginal land in the Northern Territory is a matter for private negotiation between the mining companies and the Aboriginal people concerned. I am not privy to those arrangements.

However, under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976, the Commonwealth makes payments from the Consolidated Revenue Fund to the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account equivalent to royalties paid by mining companies to the Northern Territory Government in respect of non‐uranium mining interests in Aboriginal land in the Northern Territory. In the case of uranium mining interests in Aboriginal land in the Northern Territory, the mining company pays a royalty of 5.5% to the Commonwealth and the Commonwealth makes payments from the Consolidated Revenue Fund to the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account equivalent to a royalty of 4.25%.

Of the monies paid into the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account, 40% is paid to Aboriginal Land Councils in the Northern Territory to cover their costs of administration and 30% is paid to relevant Land Councils for distribution to Aboriginal organisations in areas affected by mining. The remaining amounts are paid to incorporated bodies and groups of Aboriginal people as grants, used to supplement the administrative expenses of Land Councils or invested as accretions to the Trust Account's accumulated fund.

Annual reports of the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account are tabled in Parliament, and contain details of the Trust Account's income and expenditure. The following table shows the royalty equivalent income and expenditure of the Trust Account from its inception on 1 July 1978 to 30 June 1997. The expenditure figures reflect both statutory royalty equivalent income and other income.
